events.title: Elsie's Betrothal and an Ominous Vision in the Cellar
detailed_summary: - Elsie's parents expressed their desire for her to get married.
- A suitor named Hans appeared, specifying that his future wife, Elsie, must be exceptionally intelligent.
- Elsie's father asserted her good sense, while her mother made hyperbolic claims about her perceptive abilities, such as detecting wind and hearing flies cough.
- Hans reiterated that he would only marry her if she was truly smart.
- During dinner, Elsie was instructed by her mother to go to the cellar to fetch beer.
- Elsie took a pitcher and, to make the time pass quickly, tapped the lid as she descended.
- In the cellar, she arranged a chair by the barrel to avoid straining herself while drawing the beer.
- As the beer flowed, she scanned her surroundings and noticed a pick-axe left precariously above her by masons.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was once a man who had a daughter who was called Clever Elsie.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then she placed the can before her, and turned the tap, and while the beer was running she would not let her eyes be idle, but looked up at the wall, and after much peering here and there, saw a pick-axe exactly above her, which the masons had accidentally left there.

events.text_segment: There was once a man who had a daughter who was called Clever Elsie. And when she had grown up her father said: ‘We will get her married.’ ‘Yes,’ said the mother, ‘if only someone would come who would have her.’ At length a man came from a distance and wooed her, who was called Hans; but he stipulated that Clever Elsie should be really smart. ‘Oh,’ said the father, ‘she has plenty of good sense’; and the mother said: ‘Oh, she can see the wind coming up the street, and hear the flies coughing.’ ‘Well,’ said Hans, ‘if she is not really smart, I won’t have her.’ When they were sitting at dinner and had eaten, the mother said: ‘Elsie, go into the cellar and fetch some beer.’ Then Clever Elsie took the pitcher from the wall, went into the cellar, and tapped the lid briskly as she went, so that the time might not appear long. When she was below she fetched herself a chair, and set it before the barrel so that she had no need to stoop, and did not hurt her back or do herself any unexpected injury. Then she placed the can before her, and turned the tap, and while the beer was running she would not let her eyes be idle, but looked up at the wall, and after much peering here and there, saw a pick-axe exactly above her, which the masons had accidentally left there.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: There was once a man who had a daughter who was called Clever Elsie. When she was grown up, her father said, 'We must think about getting her married.' There came a suitor named Hans, and he wanted to woo her. But he made one condition: his wife must be very clever. The father said, 'She has a good head on her shoulders.' The mother said, 'Oh, she is as sharp as a needle, she can see the wind blowing down the street, and hear the flies coughing.' Hans said, 'Very well, but I must see for myself if she is really clever. If she is not, I will not marry her.' When they were sitting at table and had eaten, the mother said, 'Elsie, go down into the cellar and fetch us some beer.' Clever Elsie took the pitcher from the wall, and went down into the cellar. As she went down, she tapped the lid of the pitcher all the way, so that the time might not seem long. When she got into the cellar, she drew a chair up to the barrel, so that she might not have to stoop and hurt her back, and held the pitcher under the tap. As the beer was running, she looked about her, and saw a pick-axe hanging on the wall just above her head. The masons had left it there by mistake.

As the beer was running, she did not want to let her eyes be idle, and peered about. Then she saw a pick-axe hanging on the wall just above her head. The masons had left it there by mistake.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: There was once a man who had a daughter who was called Clever Elsie. When she was grown up, her father thought, "We must get her married." So he looked about for a suitable husband, and at last found a young man named Hans, who was quite well-to-do. When Hans came to visit, he sat down with Elsie's father and mother, and they talked about the marriage. Hans said, "I want to marry Clever Elsie, but I must first know if she is really clever." The father said, "Oh yes, she is very clever," and the mother added, "She can see the wind blowing up the street, and hear the flies coughing." Hans said, "Good, but I will test her myself." A little while later, the mother said, "Elsie, go down into the cellar and fetch us some beer." Elsie took a jug and went down. As she was going down the steps, she saw a pickaxe sticking out of the wall above her head. She stopped and thought, "If I marry Hans and we have a child, and he grows up and is sent down here for beer, this pickaxe might fall on his head and kill him!" She sat down on the steps and began to weep bitterly, crying about the terrible misfortune that might happen to her future child. She sat there for a long time, crying and crying, completely forgetting the beer and why she had come down.

events.title: The Cascade of Sympathetic Sorrow in the Cellar
detailed_summary: - Upon seeing the pick-axe, Elsie began to cry, imagining a future scenario where her and Hans's child would be sent to the cellar and killed by the falling tool.
- She remained in the cellar, weeping and lamenting loudly over this projected misfortune.
- When Elsie didn't return, her mother sent the servant to check on her.
- The maid found Elsie crying and, upon hearing Elsie's fears about the pick-axe and her future child, declared Elsie clever and joined in the weeping.
- As the maid also failed to return, the father sent the boy to investigate.
- The boy discovered both Elsie and the maid weeping; Elsie reiterated her concern, prompting the boy to also call her clever and join their lament.
- With the boy not returning, the mother went down herself, found all three crying, and learned of Elsie's fear for her future child.
- The mother too proclaimed Elsie clever and sat down to weep with them.
- Finally, the father, driven by thirst and the continued absence of his wife, went to the cellar.

- He found everyone crying, heard Elsie's elaborate fear about a potential child being killed by the pick-axe under very specific future circumstances, and he too exclaimed at Elsie's cleverness before joining the collective weeping.

events.text_segment: Then Clever Elsie began to weep and said: ‘If I get Hans, and we have a child, and he grows big, and we send him into the cellar here to draw beer, then the pick-axe will fall on his head and kill him.’ Then she sat and wept and screamed with all the strength of her body, over the misfortune which lay before her. Those upstairs waited for the drink, but Clever Elsie still did not come. Then the woman said to the servant: ‘Just go down into the cellar and see where Elsie is.’ The maid went and found her sitting in front of the barrel, screaming loudly. ‘Elsie why do you weep?’ asked the maid. ‘Ah,’ she answered, ‘have I not reason to weep? If I get Hans, and we have a child, and he grows big, and has to draw beer here, the pick-axe will perhaps fall on his head, and kill him.’ Then said the maid: ‘What a clever Elsie we have!’ and sat down beside her and began loudly to weep over the misfortune. After a while, as the maid did not come back, and those upstairs were thirsty for the beer, the man said to the boy: ‘Just go down into the cellar and see where Elsie and the girl are.’ The boy went down, and there sat Clever Elsie and the girl both weeping together. Then he asked: ‘Why are you weeping?’ ‘Ah,’ said Elsie, ‘have I not reason to weep? If I get Hans, and we have a child, and he grows big, and has to draw beer here, the pick-axe will fall on his head and kill him.’ Then said the boy: ‘What a clever Elsie we have!’ and sat down by her, and likewise began to howl loudly. Upstairs they waited for the boy, but as he still did not return, the man said to the woman: ‘Just go down into the cellar and see where Elsie is!’ The woman went down, and found all three in the midst of their lamentations, and inquired what was the cause; then Elsie told her also that her future child was to be killed by the pick-axe, when it grew big and had to draw beer, and the pick-axe fell down. Then said the mother likewise: ‘What a clever Elsie we have!’ and sat down and wept with them. The man upstairs waited a short time, but as his wife did not come back and his thirst grew ever greater, he said: ‘I must go into the cellar myself and see where Elsie is.’ But when he got into the cellar, and they were all sitting together crying, and he heard the reason, and that Elsie’s child was the cause, and the Elsie might perhaps bring one into the world some day, and that he might be killed by the pick-axe, if he should happen to be sitting beneath it, drawing beer just at the very time when it fell down, he cried: ‘Oh, what a clever Elsie!’ and sat down, and likewise wept with them.

When they came to the field, Hans said: ‘You go first, Elsie, and I will follow.’ So she went first, and he followed. But when she had gone a little way, she stopped and began to think. She thought: ‘If I cut the corn, and we make bread from it, and we eat the bread, and we have a child, and he grows big, and we send him to the field to cut corn, and a sickle falls on his head and kills him...’ She sat down in the field and began to weep over the misfortune that had not yet happened. Hans came after her and found her sitting there weeping. ‘Elsie, what are you doing?’ he asked. ‘I am weeping,’ she answered. ‘Why are you weeping?’ he asked. ‘Oh, dear Hans,’ she said, ‘if I cut the corn, and we make bread from it, and we eat the bread, and we have a child, and he grows big, and we send him to the field to cut corn, and a sickle falls on his head and kills him.’ Hans was very angry. ‘Clever Elsie!’ he cried. ‘You foresee misfortune before it happens, but you do nothing to prevent it! You sit here and weep instead of cutting the corn!’ And from that day on, she was known as Clever Elsie, though many thought she was anything but clever.

events.title: Hans's Curious Approval and the Unlikely Wedding
detailed_summary: - Hans, the bridegroom, waited alone upstairs for a considerable time.
- Believing the others might be waiting for him below, he decided to go to the cellar to see what was happening.
- Upon descending, he found all five individuals—Elsie, the maid, the boy, Elsie's mother, and Elsie's father—loudly screaming and lamenting.
- Hans inquired about the cause of their misfortune.
- Elsie explained her fear: if they married and had a child who was later sent to the cellar for a drink, the pick-axe might fall and kill him.
- Hans declared that such foresight was all the understanding needed for his household.
- Impressed by her perceived cleverness, he affirmed he would marry her, took her hand, and they went upstairs and were wed.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘Come,’ said Hans, ‘more understanding than that is not needed for my household, as you are such a clever Elsie, I will have you,’ and seized her hand, took her upstairs with him, and married her.

events.text_segment: The bridegroom stayed upstairs alone for a long time; then as no one would come back he thought: ‘They must be waiting for me below: I too must go there and see what they are about.’ When he got down, the five of them were sitting screaming and lamenting quite piteously, each out-doing the other. ‘What misfortune has happened then?’ asked he. ‘Ah, dear Hans,’ said Elsie, ‘if we marry each other and have a child, and he is big, and we perhaps send him here to draw something to drink, then the pick-axe which has been left up there might dash his brains out if it were to fall down, so have we not reason to weep?’ ‘Come,’ said Hans, ‘more understanding than that is not needed for my household, as you are such a clever Elsie, I will have you,’ and seized her hand, took her upstairs with him, and married her.

Hans said: ‘What misfortune has happened that you are all crying so lamentably?’ ‘Ah, Hans,’ said Elsie, ‘if we marry and have a child, and he has to be sent here to the cellar for drink, then the pick-axe will fall on his head and kill him, and as we are to lament that beforehand, we are doing it at once.’ ‘Hans,’ said the father, ‘such understanding as that is all that is needed for our household; as you have seen such foresight, you may marry her.’ And Hans took Clever Elsie by the hand, and said: ‘I want no other, and I will have you,’ and led her upstairs to his room, and courted and married her.

events.title: Elsie's Unconventional Approach to Farm Work
detailed_summary: - Sometime after their marriage, Hans told Elsie he was going out to earn money and instructed her to go to the field to cut corn for bread.
- Elsie agreed to do so.
- After Hans left, she prepared some broth and took it with her to the field.
- Upon arriving at the field, she debated whether to cut the corn first or eat first, ultimately deciding to eat.
- After finishing her broth and feeling satisfied, she then deliberated between cutting the corn and sleeping, choosing to sleep.
- She lay down among the corn and fell asleep.
- Hans, having been home for a while and noting Elsie's absence, ironically praised her supposed diligence, assuming she was too busy working to return for a meal.
- When evening arrived and Elsie had still not returned, Hans went to the field to see her progress.
- He discovered that no corn had been cut and found Elsie asleep in the field.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After Hans had had her some time, he said: ‘Wife, I am going out to work and earn some money for us; go into the field and cut the corn that we may have some bread.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But when evening came and she still stayed away, Hans went out to see what she had cut, but nothing was cut, and she was lying among the corn asleep.

events.text_segment: After Hans had had her some time, he said: ‘Wife, I am going out to work and earn some money for us; go into the field and cut the corn that we may have some bread.’ ‘Yes, dear Hans, I will do that.’ After Hans had gone away, she cooked herself some good broth and took it into the field with her. When she came to the field she said to herself: ‘What shall I do; shall I cut first, or shall I eat first? Oh, I will eat first.’ Then she drank her cup of broth and when she was fully satisfied, she once more said: ‘What shall I do? Shall I cut first, or shall I sleep first? I will sleep first.’ Then she lay down among the corn and fell asleep. Hans had been at home for a long time, but Elsie did not come; then said he: ‘What a clever Elsie I have; she is so industrious that she does not even come home to eat.’ But when evening came and she still stayed away, Hans went out to see what she had cut, but nothing was cut, and she was lying among the corn asleep.

events.title: The Jingling Bells and Elsie's Existential Crisis
detailed_summary: - Upon finding Elsie asleep, Hans quickly returned home and brought a fowler's net adorned with little bells, which he hung around her while she continued to sleep.
- He then ran back home, shut the house door, sat in his chair, and resumed working.
- When it was quite dark, Clever Elsie finally awoke.
- As she stood up, she was surrounded by a jingling sound, with bells ringing at her every step.
- This alarmed her and made her deeply uncertain about her own identity, causing her to wonder aloud if she was truly Clever Elsie.
- Unable to resolve this doubt, she decided to go home and ask, believing they would know.
- She ran to her house door but found it shut; she knocked on the window and called out to Hans, asking if Elsie was inside.
- Hans replied from within that Elsie was indeed inside.
- This terrified Elsie, convincing her that she was not herself.
- She then went to another door, but the people there, hearing the jingling bells, refused to open it, leaving her unable to find entry anywhere.
- Consequently, she fled the village, and her whereabouts thereafter remained unknown.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then Hans hastened home and brought a fowler’s net with little bells and hung it round about her, and she still went on sleeping.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then she ran out of the village, and no one has seen her since.

events.text_segment: Then Hans hastened home and brought a fowler’s net with little bells and hung it round about her, and she still went on sleeping. Then he ran home, shut the house-door, and sat down in his chair and worked. At length, when it was quite dark, Clever Elsie awoke and when she got up there was a jingling all round about her, and the bells rang at each step which she took. Then she was alarmed, and became uncertain whether she really was Clever Elsie or not, and said: ‘Is it I, or is it not I?’ But she knew not what answer to make to this, and stood for a time in doubt; at length she thought: ‘I will go home and ask if it be I, or if it be not I, they will be sure to know.’ She ran to the door of her own house, but it was shut; then she knocked at the window and cried: ‘Hans, is Elsie within?’ ‘Yes,’ answered Hans, ‘she is within.’ Hereupon she was terrified, and said: ‘Ah, heavens! Then it is not I,’ and went to another door; but when the people heard the jingling of the bells they would not open it, and she could get in nowhere. Then she ran out of the village, and no one has seen her since.

events.title: The Servant's Departure with Meager Pay
detailed_summary: A loyal servant, after three years of dedicated but unpaid labor for his master, finally requested the wages he was owed.
The master, characterized as a severe miser, recognized his servant's simple nature and decided to exploit it, giving him only three pence – one penny for each year of service.
The naive servant, believing this to be a substantial amount of money, felt a sense of newfound wealth and freedom.
He resolved to abandon his difficult life of hard work and poor sustenance, deciding instead to travel the world and enjoy himself.
With this resolution, he placed his meager earnings into his purse and embarked on his journey, wandering through the countryside.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A farmer had a faithful and diligent servant, who had worked hard for him three years, without having been paid any wages.

events.text_segment: A farmer had a faithful and diligent servant, who had worked hard for him three years, without having been paid any wages. At last it came into the man’s head that he would not go on thus without pay any longer; so he went to his master, and said, ‘I have worked hard for you a long time, I will trust to you to give me what I deserve to have for my trouble.’ The farmer was a sad miser, and knew that his man was very simple-hearted; so he took out threepence, and gave him for every year’s service a penny. The poor fellow thought it was a great deal of money to have, and said to himself, ‘Why should I work hard, and live here on bad fare any longer? I can now travel into the wide world, and make myself merry.’ With that he put his money into his purse, and set out, roaming over hill and valley.

At last it came into the servant's head that he would not serve any longer without pay, so he went to his master and said, 'I have served you now three years, and have had no wages; I wish you would pay me, and let me go, for I should like to see the world a little, and try my luck.' The master answered, 'You have been a faithful and diligent servant, and shall be paid handsomely.' And with that he gave him three pence, one for each year. The poor servant, who knew nothing about money, thought it was a great deal, and said, 'Well, now I am a rich man, and need not work any more; but will travel about and see the world.' So he put his money into his purse, and went away singing and dancing over the fields.

events.title: Encounter with the Dwarf and the Granting of Three Wishes
detailed_summary: As the countryman journeyed cheerfully, singing and dancing, he was approached by a small dwarf who questioned the source of his happiness.
The countryman explained that his joy stemmed from his good health and his supposed riches, revealing his three pence savings.
The dwarf, stating he was very poor, requested the money from the countryman.
Moved by pity, the kind-hearted countryman gave the dwarf all of his money.

As a reward for his generosity and honest heart, the dwarf granted him three wishes: a bow that would never miss its target, a fiddle whose music would compel anyone who heard it to dance, and the ability to have any request he made granted.
The dwarf then provided the magical bow and fiddle to the countryman and departed.

events.text_segment: As he jogged along over the fields, singing and dancing, a little dwarf met him, and asked him what made him so merry. ‘Why, what should make me down-hearted?’ said he; ‘I am sound in health and rich in purse, what should I care for? I have saved up my three years’ earnings and have it all safe in my pocket.’ ‘How much may it come to?’ said the little man. ‘Full threepence,’ replied the countryman. ‘I wish you would give them to me,’ said the other; ‘I am very poor.’ Then the man pitied him, and gave him all he had; and the little dwarf said in return, ‘As you have such a kind honest heart, I will grant you three wishes—one for every penny; so choose whatever you like.’ Then the countryman rejoiced at his good luck, and said, ‘I like many things better than money: first, I will have a bow that will bring down everything I shoot at; secondly, a fiddle that will set everyone dancing that hears me play upon it; and thirdly, I should like that everyone should grant what I ask.’ The dwarf said he should have his three wishes; so he gave him the bow and fiddle, and went his way.

events.title: The Countryman Outwits a Miser Using His Magical Gifts
detailed_summary: The countryman continued his journey, his spirits even higher than before, and soon encountered an old miser.
Nearby, a thrush sang joyfully from the top of a tree, and the miser expressed a strong desire to possess the bird, claiming he would pay a great sum for it.
The countryman offered to retrieve the bird and, using his magical bow, shot the thrush, causing it to fall into a thorny bush at the tree's base.
As the miser ventured into the dense bush to find the bird, the countryman began to play his magical fiddle.
The music irresistibly forced the miser to dance and leap among the thorns, which tore his clothes to shreds and left him scratched and bleeding.
The miser, in agony, begged the countryman to stop the music, pleading his innocence and asking what he had done to deserve such treatment.
The countryman retorted that the miser was merely receiving his due for having exploited many poor people, and he continued to play.

Desperate, the miser started offering money for his release, gradually increasing his bids as the countryman played faster tunes, until he finally offered a hundred florins – money he had recently acquired by cheating someone.
Seeing this substantial sum, the countryman agreed, took the purse, ceased playing, and contentedly resumed his travels.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Our honest friend journeyed on his way too; and if he was merry before, he was now ten times more so.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So he took the purse, put up his fiddle, and travelled on very pleased with his bargain.

events.text_segment: Our honest friend journeyed on his way too; and if he was merry before, he was now ten times more so. He had not gone far before he met an old miser: close by them stood a tree, and on the topmost twig sat a thrush singing away most joyfully. ‘Oh, what a pretty bird!’ said the miser; ‘I would give a great deal of money to have such a one.’ ‘If that’s all,’ said the countryman, ‘I will soon bring it down.’ Then he took up his bow, and down fell the thrush into the bushes at the foot of the tree. The miser crept into the bush to find it; but directly he had got into the middle, his companion took up his fiddle and played away, and the miser began to dance and spring about, capering higher and higher in the air. The thorns soon began to tear his clothes till they all hung in rags about him, and he himself was all scratched and wounded, so that the blood ran down. ‘Oh, for heaven’s sake!’ cried the miser, ‘Master! master! pray let the fiddle alone. What have I done to deserve this?’ ‘Thou hast shaved many a poor soul close enough,’ said the other; ‘thou art only meeting thy reward’: so he played up another tune. Then the miser began to beg and promise, and offered money for his liberty; but he did not come up to the musician’s price for some time, and he danced him along brisker and brisker, and the miser bid higher and higher, till at last he offered a round hundred of florins that he had in his purse, and had just gained by cheating some poor fellow. When the countryman saw so much money, he said, ‘I will agree to your proposal.’ So he took the purse, put up his fiddle, and travelled on very pleased with his bargain.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Our honest friend journeyed on his way too; and if he was merry before, he was now ten times more so. He had not gone far before he met an old miser, who was creeping along, and picking up everything he could find, and putting it into his sack. The musician wished him good-day, and played a tune that was so merry that the old man forgot his rags and his bag, and began to dance. After a while, as he was capering about, a thrush sang so sweetly on the top of a tree that the miser stopped and said, "Oh, dear musician, what a beautiful bird! I would give a great deal of money to have such a one. If you could catch it for me, I would thank you for ever." "With all my heart," said the musician; "if you will give me a good price for it." The miser said he would give him whatever he asked. Then the musician took his bow, and shot the thrush, and it fell into a thorny bush at the foot of the tree. "Now go and fetch it yourself," said the musician. "Oh, no," said the miser, "my clothes are old and torn enough already; you must go in." So the musician went in, and as he was coming out with the bird, the miser began to grumble, and said, "What do you want for your trouble? You have done nothing but run into a bush." "You promised to give me whatever I asked," said the musician; "so you must give me a hundred florins." "A hundred florins!" cried the miser; "do you think I am made of money?" "You said you would give me whatever I asked," said the musician; "and if you do not, I will play you a tune that you will not like." So he began to play, and the miser began to dance and leap about among the thorns, which tore his clothes to rags, and scratched and wounded him from head to foot. "Oh, stop! stop!" cried the miser; "I will give you the money." "No," said the musician, "you must dance till you are tired." And he played faster and faster, and the miser danced and leaped higher and higher, till the thorns tore him all to pieces. At last he could bear it no longer, and cried out, "Take the money! take the money! I have it all in my bag; I have just been cheating a poor man out of it." So the musician stopped, and took the bag, and counted out a hundred florins, and put them into his pocket. "Now," said he, "you may go and fetch your bird yourself." And he went on his way, and left the miser to get the thrush out of the bush as well as he could.

events.title: The Miser's Revenge Plot and the Countryman's Arrest
detailed_summary: Meanwhile, the miser, emerging from the bush half-dressed and in a wretched state, began to plot how he could exact revenge on the countryman.
He proceeded to the local judge and lodged a complaint, accusing a scoundrel of robbing him of his money and assaulting him, describing the culprit as carrying a bow and a fiddle.
Acting on this complaint, the judge dispatched his officers with instructions to find and apprehend the man matching the description.
The countryman was soon located by the officers, arrested, and brought before the judge to stand trial.

events.title: The Final Request and the Fiddle's Compulsory Dance
detailed_summary: As he stood on the steps of the gallows, the countryman made a final request to the judge.
The judge agreed to grant any request except for his life; the countryman clarified he only wished to play his fiddle one last time.
The miser vehemently protested, begging the judge not to allow it.
Despite the miser's pleas, the judge consented, stating it would be brief; this compliance was influenced by the dwarf's third gift, which compelled people to grant the countryman's requests.
Panicked, the miser cried out to be tied securely.
The countryman then took his fiddle and began to play. Instantly, the judge, clerks, and jailer started to move and caper, and no one could restrain the miser.

At the second note, the hangman released the countryman and also began dancing. By the time the first bar of the tune was played, everyone present—judge, court officials, the miser, and all the spectators—was dancing uncontrollably.
Initially, the scene was somewhat amusing, but as the music and dancing continued without end, the participants began to cry out, begging the countryman to stop.
He paid no heed to their pleas until the judge not only granted him his life but also promised the return of the hundred florins.

events.text_segment:
So away he was taken; but as he stood on the steps he said, ‘My Lord Judge, grant me one last request.’ ‘Anything but thy life,’ replied the other. ‘No,’ said he, ‘I do not ask my life; only to let me play upon my fiddle for the last time.’ The miser cried out, ‘Oh, no! no! for heaven’s sake don’t listen to him! don’t listen to him!’ But the judge said, ‘It is only this once, he will soon have done.’ The fact was, he could not refuse the request, on account of the dwarf’s third gift.
Then the miser said, ‘Bind me fast, bind me fast, for pity’s sake.’ But the countryman seized his fiddle, and struck up a tune, and at the first note judge, clerks, and jailer were in motion; all began capering, and no one could hold the miser. At the second note the hangman let his prisoner go, and danced also, and by the time he had played the first bar of the tune, all were dancing together—judge, court, and miser, and all the people who had followed to look on. At first the thing was merry and pleasant enough; but when it had gone on a while, and there seemed to be no end of playing or dancing, they began to cry out, and beg him to leave off; but he stopped not a whit the more for their entreaties, till the judge not only gave him his life, but promised to return him the hundred florins.

But the judge said, ‘It is only for a moment, and it can do no harm,’ and he consented, for the dwarf’s third gift, which compelled people to grant whatever the countryman asked, was already at work upon him. The miser cried out, ‘Oh, tie me fast, tie me fast, or I shall have to dance against my will!’

events.title: Justice Restored and the Miser's Public Confession
detailed_summary: Once the judge had agreed to spare his life and return the money, the countryman addressed the miser directly.
He warned the miser, whom he called a vagabond, to reveal how he had obtained the gold, threatening to resume playing the fiddle solely for the miser's torment if he refused.
Compelled and in the presence of all the assembled people, the miser confessed that he had stolen the gold.
The miser also acknowledged that the countryman had earned the money fairly.
Having extracted this public confession, the countryman ceased playing his fiddle, thereby leaving the now-exposed thief, the miser, to face execution in his stead.

events.title: Mother's Death, Father's Remarriage, and Ashputtel's Torment
detailed_summary: A wealthy man's wife, on her deathbed, instructed her only daughter to always be good, promising to watch over her from heaven.
Following her mother's death and burial in the garden, the little girl visited the grave daily, wept, and remained consistently good and kind.
After snow covered the grave and melted with the spring, the girl's father remarried.
The new wife brought her two daughters, who were fair-faced but malevolent at heart, marking the beginning of a difficult time for the little girl.
The stepsisters demeaned her, questioning her place in the parlor and asserting that she should earn her keep, ultimately calling for her to be a kitchen-maid.
They confiscated her fine clothes, gave her an old grey frock, mocked her, and confined her to the kitchen.
She was compelled to perform arduous labor: waking before dawn, carrying water, tending the fire, cooking, and washing.
Additionally, her stepsisters tormented her relentlessly and ridiculed her.
In the evenings, tired from her work, she had no bed and was forced to sleep by the hearth among the ashes, which made her perpetually dusty and dirty, leading them to call her Ashputtel.

events.text_segment:
The wife of a rich man fell sick; and when she felt that her end drew nigh, she called her only daughter to her bed-side, and said, ‘Always be a good girl, and I will look down from heaven and watch over you.’ Soon afterwards she shut her eyes and died, and was buried in the garden; and the little girl went every day to her grave and wept, and was always good and kind to all about her. And the snow fell and spread a beautiful white covering over the grave; but by the time the spring came, and the sun had melted it away again, her father had married another wife. This new wife had two daughters of her own, that she brought home with her; they were fair in face but foul at heart, and it was now a sorry time for the poor little girl. ‘What does the good-for-nothing want in the parlour?’ said they; ‘they who would eat bread should first earn it; away with the kitchen-maid!’ Then they took away her fine clothes, and gave her an old grey frock to put on, and laughed at her, and turned her into the kitchen.
There she was forced to do hard work; to rise early before daylight, to bring the water, to make the fire, to cook and to wash. Besides that, the sisters plagued her in all sorts of ways, and laughed at her. In the evening when she was tired, she had no bed to lie down on, but was made to lie by the hearth among the ashes; and as this, of course, made her always dusty and dirty, they called her Ashputtel.

events.title: The Hazel Twig and the Magical Tree
detailed_summary: On one occasion, the father, planning to attend a fair, asked his wife's daughters what gifts they desired.
The first requested 'Fine clothes,' while the second asked for 'Pearls and diamonds.'
Addressing his own daughter, Ashputtel, he asked for her wish.
She requested the first twig that would brush against his hat as he turned to come homewards.
He purchased the fine clothes, pearls, and diamonds for the stepdaughters.
On his way home, riding through a green copse, a hazel twig struck his hat, nearly dislodging it; he broke off the twig and took it with him.
Upon reaching home, he gave the twig to his daughter.
She took the twig, planted it on her mother's grave, and wept so profusely that her tears watered it.
The twig grew into a fine tree.
Ashputtel visited the tree three times daily and wept; soon, a little bird built its nest on the tree, communicated with her, watched over her, and brought her whatever she wished for.

events.text_segment: It happened once that the father was going to the fair, and asked his wife’s daughters what he should bring them. ‘Fine clothes,’ said the first; ‘Pearls and diamonds,’ cried the second. ‘Now, child,’ said he to his own daughter, ‘what will you have?’ ‘The first twig, dear father, that brushes against your hat when you turn your face to come homewards,’ said she. Then he bought for the first two the fine clothes and pearls and diamonds they had asked for: and on his way home, as he rode through a green copse, a hazel twig brushed against him, and almost pushed off his hat: so he broke it off and brought it away; and when he got home he gave it to his daughter. Then she took it, and went to her mother’s grave and planted it there; and cried so much that it was watered with her tears; and there it grew and became a fine tree. Three times every day she went to it and cried; and soon a little bird came and built its nest upon the tree, and talked with her, and watched over her, and brought her whatever she wished for.

events.title: The King's Feast and Ashputtel's Plea for Attendance
detailed_summary: The king of the land announced a feast lasting three days, from which his son would choose a bride.
Ashputtel's two stepsisters were invited to attend.
They summoned Ashputtel, ordering her to comb their hair, brush their shoes, and tie their sashes for the king's feast.
Ashputtel complied, but afterwards, she couldn't help crying because she dearly wished to go to the ball with them.
She persistently begged her stepmother to allow her to go.
The stepmother derided her, pointing out Ashputtel's lack of clothes and inability to dance.
When Ashputtel continued begging, the stepmother, to get rid of her, proposed a challenge: if Ashputtel could pick a dishful of peas from the ash-heap within two hours, she could attend the feast.

events.text_segment: Now it happened that the king of that land held a feast, which was to last three days; and out of those who came to it his son was to choose a bride for himself. Ashputtel’s two sisters were asked to come; so they called her up, and said, ‘Now, comb our hair, brush our shoes, and tie our sashes for us, for we are going to dance at the king’s feast.’ Then she did as she was told; but when all was done she could not help crying, for she thought to herself, she should so have liked to have gone with them to the ball; and at last she begged her mother very hard to let her go. ‘You, Ashputtel!’ said she; ‘you who have nothing to wear, no clothes at all, and who cannot even dance—you want to go to the ball? And when she kept on begging, she said at last, to get rid of her, ‘I will throw this dishful of peas into the ash-heap, and if in two hours’ time you have picked them all out, you shall go to the feast too.’

events.title: First Pea-Picking Task, Magical Aid, and Stepmother's Escalating Challenge
detailed_summary: The stepmother scattered the peas into the ashes.
Ashputtel went out the back door into the garden and called for turtle-doves, linnets, blackbirds, thrushes, chaffinches, and all birds to come and help her pick the peas.
Two white doves arrived first at the kitchen window, followed by two turtle-doves, and then all the small birds from heaven, chirping and fluttering.
The birds flew down into the ashes, and the doves began picking, followed by the others.
Collectively, they quickly sorted all the good grain into a dish, leaving the ashes behind.
The task was completed well before the allocated two hours, and all the birds flew out the windows.
Ashputtel, overjoyed at the prospect of attending the ball, brought the dish to her stepmother.
The stepmother, however, dismissed her, stating she had no clothes and couldn't dance, so she would not go.
When Ashputtel pleaded intensely, the stepmother, intending to dissuade her, set a new condition: Ashputtel must pick two dishes of peas from the ashes in one hour to be allowed to go.
The stepmother thought this would finally rid her of Ashputtel's pestering, so she poured two dishes of peas into the ashes.

events.text_segment:
Then she threw the peas down among the ashes, but the little maiden ran out at the back door into the garden, and cried out:
‘Hither, hither, through the sky,
  Turtle-doves and linnets, fly!
  Blackbird, thrush, and chaffinch gay,
  Hither, hither, haste away!

  Haste ye, haste ye!—pick, pick, pick!’
Then first came two white doves, flying in at the kitchen window; next came two turtle-doves; and after them came all the little birds under heaven, chirping and fluttering in: and they flew down into the ashes. And the little doves stooped their heads down and set to work, pick, pick, pick; and then the others began to pick, pick, pick: and among them all they soon picked out all the good grain, and put it into a dish but left the ashes. Long before the end of the hour the work was quite done, and all flew out again at the windows.
Then Ashputtel brought the dish to her mother, overjoyed at the thought that now she should go to the ball. But the mother said, ‘No, no! you slut, you have no clothes, and cannot dance; you shall not go.’ And when Ashputtel begged very hard to go, she said, ‘If you can in one hour’s time pick two of those dishes of peas out of the ashes, you shall go too.’ And thus she thought she should at least get rid of her. So she shook two dishes of peas into the ashes.

events.title: First Night at the Ball: Magical Attire, Royal Dance, and Cunning Escape
detailed_summary: Once everyone had left for the ball, Ashputtel went sadly to the hazel-tree and uttered a charm for gold and silver.
Her avian friend flew from the tree, bringing her a dress of gold and silver and slippers of spangled silk.
She put on the attire and went to the feast, following her sisters.
Her stepsisters did not recognize her, assuming she was a foreign princess due to her fine appearance, taking it for granted that Ashputtel was at home in the dirt.
The king's son approached her, took her hand, and danced exclusively with her, never releasing her hand.
If anyone else asked her to dance, he would state that she was already dancing with him.
They danced late into the night; when she wished to go home, the king's son offered to escort her, wanting to see where she lived.
She managed to slip away from him unnoticed and ran towards home.
As the prince followed, she jumped into the pigeon-house and shut the door.
The prince waited until her father returned and told him the unknown maiden from the feast had hidden there.
However, when they broke open the pigeon-house door, they found no one inside.
Upon returning to the main house, Ashputtel was found lying in her dirty frock by the ashes, her dim lamp burning, having swiftly changed at the hazel-tree and returned her finery to the bird.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: For she had run as quickly as she could through the pigeon-house and on to the hazel-tree, and had there taken off her beautiful clothes, and put them beneath the tree, that the bird might carry them away, and had lain down again amid the ashes in her little grey frock.

events.text_segment:
Now when all were gone, and nobody left at home, Ashputtel went sorrowfully and sat down under the hazel-tree, and cried out:
‘Shake, shake, hazel-tree,
  Gold and silver over me!’
Then her friend the bird flew out of the tree, and brought a gold and silver dress for her, and slippers of spangled silk; and she put them on, and followed her sisters to the feast. But they did not know her, and thought it must be some strange princess, she looked so fine and beautiful in her rich clothes; and they never once thought of Ashputtel, taking it for granted that she was safe at home in the dirt.
The king’s son soon came up to her, and took her by the hand and danced with her, and no one else: and he never left her hand; but when anyone else came to ask her to dance, he said, ‘This lady is dancing with me.’
Thus they danced till a late hour of the night; and then she wanted to go home: and the king’s son said, ‘I shall go and take care of you to your home’; for he wanted to see where the beautiful maiden lived. But she slipped away from him, unawares, and ran off towards home; and as the prince followed her, she jumped up into the pigeon-house and shut the door. Then he waited till her father came home, and told him that the unknown maiden, who had been at the feast, had hid herself in the pigeon-house. But when they had broken open the door they found no one within; and as they came back into the house, Ashputtel was lying, as she always did, in her dirty frock by the ashes, and her dim little lamp was burning in the chimney. For she had run as quickly as she could through the pigeon-house and on to the hazel-tree, and had there taken off her beautiful clothes, and put them beneath the tree, that the bird might carry them away, and had lain down again amid the ashes in her little grey frock.

events.title: Second Night at the Ball: Enhanced Splendor, Continued Royal Favor, and Pear-Tree Evasion
detailed_summary: The next day, as the feast continued and her family departed, Ashputtel went to the hazel-tree and repeated her request.
The bird brought her a dress even finer than the one from the previous day.
When she arrived at the ball in this attire, everyone marveled at her beauty.
The king's son, who was waiting for her, took her hand and danced with her exclusively, reiterating to others that she was his dancing partner.
When night came and she wanted to go home, the king's son followed her again, hoping to see which house she entered.
She suddenly sprang away from him into the garden behind her father's house.
This garden contained a large pear-tree full of ripe fruit, and Ashputtel, unsure where else to hide, climbed into it without being seen.
The king's son lost sight of her and, upon her father's return, told him the unknown lady must have sprung into the pear-tree.
The father, wondering if it could be Ashputtel, had an axe brought, and they cut down the tree but found no one.
Meanwhile, Ashputtel had climbed down the other side of the tree, returned her beautiful clothes to the bird at the hazel-tree, and put on her little grey frock, resuming her place by the ashes.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The next day when the feast was again held, and her father, mother, and sisters were gone, Ashputtel went to the hazel-tree, and said:

events.text_segment:
The next day when the feast was again held, and her father, mother, and sisters were gone, Ashputtel went to the hazel-tree, and said:
‘Shake, shake, hazel-tree,
  Gold and silver over me!’
And the bird came and brought a still finer dress than the one she had worn the day before. And when she came in it to the ball, everyone wondered at her beauty: but the king’s son, who was waiting for her, took her by the hand, and danced with her; and when anyone asked her to dance, he said as before, ‘This lady is dancing with me.’
When night came she wanted to go home; and the king’s son followed here as before, that he might see into what house she went: but she sprang away from him all at once into the garden behind her father’s house. In this garden stood a fine large pear-tree full of ripe fruit; and Ashputtel, not knowing where to hide herself, jumped up into it without being seen. Then the king’s son lost sight of her, and could not find out where she was gone, but waited till her father came home, and said to him, ‘The unknown lady who danced with me has slipped away, and I think she must have sprung into the pear-tree.’ The father thought to himself, ‘Can it be Ashputtel?’ So he had an axe brought; and they cut down the tree, but found no one upon it. And when they came back into the kitchen, there lay Ashputtel among the ashes; for she had slipped down on the other side of the tree, and carried her beautiful clothes back to the bird at the hazel-tree, and then put on her little grey frock.

events.title: Third Night at the Ball: Supreme Elegance, Lost Golden Slipper, and Prince's Vow

The king's son danced only with her, and if anyone else asked her to dance, he would state, 'This lady is my partner, sir.'

The next day, he went to his father, the king, and declared he would take for his wife the lady whom the golden slipper fits.

The next day, he went to his father, the king, and said, "I will take for my wife the lady whom this golden slipper fits."

events.title: The Slipper Test: Stepsisters' Mutilation, Deception, and Exposure by the Dove
detailed_summary: Both stepsisters were overjoyed to hear the prince's vow, as they had beautiful feet and were confident they could wear the golden slipper.
The eldest went first into the room where the slipper was, with her mother standing by, intending to try it on.
However, her great toe could not fit into it, and the shoe was far too small for her overall.
Her mother gave her a knife, advising her to cut off her toe, reasoning that as a queen, she wouldn't need to walk or care about toes.
The girl cut off her great toe, squeezed her foot into the shoe, and went to the king's son.
He took her as his bride, set her beside him on his horse, and rode away with her homewards.
On their way, they had to pass the hazel-tree Ashputtel had planted, where a little dove on a branch sang a warning about the shoe being too small and bloodied, revealing she was not the true bride.
The prince dismounted, looked at her foot, and saw from the streaming blood the trick she had played.
He turned his horse around, brought the false bride back to her home, and stated she was not the right one, requesting the other sister try the slipper.
The second sister went into the room and managed to get her foot into the shoe, except for her heel, which was too large.
Her mother forced her heel in until blood came, and then took her to the king's son.
He set her as his bride by his side on his horse and rode away with her.
When they came to the hazel-tree, the little dove was still there and sang the same warning about the shoe and the false bride.
The prince looked down and saw so much blood streaming from the shoe that her white stockings were quite red.
So he turned his horse and brought her also back again.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then both the sisters were overjoyed to hear it; for they had beautiful feet, and had no doubt that they could wear the golden slipper.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So he turned his horse and brought her also back again.

events.text_segment:
Then both the sisters were overjoyed to hear it; for they had beautiful feet, and had no doubt that they could wear the golden slipper. The eldest went first into the room where the slipper was, and wanted to try it on, and the mother stood by. But her great toe could not go into it, and the shoe was altogether much too small for her. Then the mother gave her a knife, and said, ‘Never mind, cut it off; when you are queen you will not care about toes; you will not want to walk.’ So the silly girl cut off her great toe, and thus squeezed on the shoe, and went to the king’s son. Then he took her for his bride, and set her beside him on his horse, and rode away with her homewards.
But on their way home they had to pass by the hazel-tree that Ashputtel had planted; and on the branch sat a little dove singing:
‘Back again! back again! look to the shoe!
  The shoe is too small, and not made for you!
  Prince! prince! look again for thy bride,
  For she’s not the true one that sits by thy side.’
Then the prince got down and looked at her foot; and he saw, by the blood that streamed from it, what a trick she had played him. So he turned his horse round, and brought the false bride back to her home, and said, ‘This is not the right bride; let the other sister try and put on the slipper.’ Then she went into the room and got her foot into the shoe, all but the heel, which was too large. But her mother squeezed it in till the blood came, and took her to the king’s son: and he set her as his bride by his side on his horse, and rode away with her.
But when they came to the hazel-tree the little dove sat there still, and sang:
‘Back again! back again! look to the shoe!
  The shoe is too small, and not made for you!
  Prince! prince! look again for thy bride,
  For she’s not the true one that sits by thy side.’
Then he looked down, and saw that the blood streamed so much from the shoe, that her white stockings were quite red. So he turned his horse and brought her also back again.

events.title: Ashputtel Revealed: The Slipper Fits, True Identity Recognized, and Joyful Union
detailed_summary: The prince declared to the father that this was not the true bride and inquired if he had any other daughters.
The father replied no, mentioning only 'a little dirty Ashputtel,' his first wife's child, whom he was sure could not be the bride.
The prince insisted that she be sent for.
The stepmother protested, saying Ashputtel was far too dirty and would not dare show herself.
However, the prince was resolute in wanting her to come.
Ashputtel first washed her face and hands, then went in and curtsied to him, and he handed her the golden slipper.
She removed her clumsy shoe from her left foot and put on the golden slipper, which fitted her perfectly, as if it had been made for her.
When the prince drew near and looked at her face, he recognized her and declared, 'This is the right bride.'
The stepmother and both sisters were frightened and turned pale with anger as he took Ashputtel on his horse and rode away with her.
As they came to the hazel-tree, the white dove sang a song confirming the shoe was made for her, she was a princess, and the true bride by the prince's side.
After finishing its song, the dove flew down, perched upon Ashputtel's right shoulder, and accompanied her home.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And when the dove had done its song, it came flying, and perched upon her right shoulder, and so went home with her.

events.text_segment:
‘This is not the true bride,’ said he to the father; ‘have you no other daughters?’ ‘No,’ said he; ‘there is only a little dirty Ashputtel here, the child of my first wife; I am sure she cannot be the bride.’ The prince told him to send her. But the mother said, ‘No, no, she is much too dirty; she will not dare to show herself.’ However, the prince would have her come; and she first washed her face and hands, and then went in and curtsied to him, and he reached her the golden slipper. Then she took her clumsy shoe off her left foot, and put on the golden slipper; and it fitted her as if it had been made for her. And when he drew near and looked at her face he knew her, and said, ‘This is the right bride.’ But the mother and both the sisters were frightened, and turned pale with anger as he took Ashputtel on his horse, and rode away with her. And when they came to the hazel-tree, the white dove sang:
‘Home! home! look at the shoe!
  Princess! the shoe was made for you!
  Prince! prince! take home thy bride,
  For she is the true one that sits by thy side!’
And when the dove had done its song, it came flying, and perched upon her right shoulder, and so went home with her.

events.title: The King's Mysterious Daily Dish
detailed_summary: A long time ago, a king renowned for his profound wisdom ruled his land.
It appeared that no secrets were kept from him, as if information about the most confidential matters was mysteriously conveyed to him.
This king, however, maintained a peculiar daily practice.
Every day after dinner, when the dining table was cleared and all other attendees had departed, a loyal servant was tasked with bringing him one final dish.
This dish was always presented covered, and its contents were unknown even to the servant who delivered it.
The king would only remove the cover and consume its contents when he was entirely by himself, ensuring the nature of this meal remained a complete mystery to everyone else.

events.text_segment: A long time ago there lived a king who was famed for his wisdom through all the land. Nothing was hidden from him, and it seemed as if news of the most secret things was brought to him through the air. But he had a strange custom; every day after dinner, when the table was cleared, and no one else was present, a trusty servant had to bring him one more dish. It was covered, however, and even the servant did not know what was in it, neither did anyone know, for the king never took off the cover to eat of it until he was quite alone.

events.title: The Servant's Discovery and Acquired Animal Speech
detailed_summary: This routine continued for an extended period until one day, the servant responsible for removing the special dish was overcome by intense curiosity.
He found himself unable to resist the urge and secretly carried the covered dish into his own room.
After carefully securing the door, he lifted the cover of the dish.
Upon doing so, he discovered a white snake lying on it.
The sight of the snake was compelling, and he could not resist tasting it.
He cut off a small portion of the snake and placed it in his mouth.
The moment the piece of snake touched his tongue, he heard peculiar, soft whispering voices originating from outside his window.
He approached the window to listen more closely and discerned that it was sparrows chattering amongst themselves.
The sparrows were discussing various things they had observed in the fields and forests.
The act of eating the snake had bestowed upon him the ability to understand the language of animals.

events.title: Accusation, Animal Aid, and Exoneration
detailed_summary: Coincidentally, on that very same day, the queen misplaced her most cherished and beautiful ring.
Suspicion for the theft quickly fell upon the trusted servant, as his duties allowed him access to all areas of the palace.
The king summoned the servant and angrily threatened him with execution if he could not identify the actual thief by the following day.
The servant's declarations of innocence were futile; he was dismissed without any favorable resolution.
Overwhelmed with distress and fear, he descended into the courtyard, desperately trying to devise a plan to escape his predicament.
He noticed some ducks resting quietly by a brook, preening their feathers and engaging in what seemed like a private conversation.
The servant stood nearby and listened intently, now able to understand their discussion.
The ducks were recounting their morning activities, the places they had waddled, and the good food they had found.
One duck then complained in a pitiful tone about a heavy feeling in its stomach, admitting it had hastily swallowed a ring found beneath the queen’s window while eating.
Recognizing the opportunity, the servant immediately grabbed the duck by its neck and carried it to the kitchen.
He instructed the cook to kill and prepare the duck.
The cook, after weighing the duck, remarked on its plumpness, noting it seemed well-fattened and ready for roasting.
The cook then decapitated the duck, and as it was being prepared for cooking, the queen’s lost ring was discovered inside it.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So he cut off her head, and as she was being dressed for the spit, the queen’s ring was found inside her.

events.text_segment:
Now it so happened that on this very day the queen lost her most beautiful ring, and suspicion of having stolen it fell upon this trusty servant, who was allowed to go everywhere. The king ordered the man to be brought before him, and threatened with angry words that unless he could before the morrow point out the thief, he himself should be looked upon as guilty and executed. In vain he declared his innocence; he was dismissed with no better answer.
In his trouble and fear he went down into the courtyard and took thought how to help himself out of his trouble. Now some ducks were sitting together quietly by a brook and taking their rest; and, whilst they were making their feathers smooth with their bills, they were having a confidential conversation together. The servant stood by and listened. They were telling one another of all the places where they had been waddling about all the morning, and what good food they had found; and one said in a pitiful tone: ‘Something lies heavy on my stomach; as I was eating in haste I swallowed a ring which lay under the queen’s window.’ The servant at once seized her by the neck, carried her to the kitchen, and said to the cook: ‘Here is a fine duck; pray, kill her.’ ‘Yes,’ said the cook, and weighed her in his hand; ‘she has spared no trouble to fatten herself, and has been waiting to be roasted long enough.’ So he cut off her head, and as she was being dressed for the spit, the queen’s ring was found inside her.

There sat his ducks peaceably by a brook, and preened themselves, and held a confidential conversation. He stood by and listened to them, and as he had eaten of the white snake, he understood the language of the animals. They were relating to each other all that they had seen and how they had fared that morning, and one complained in a piteous tone, and said, 'Something lies heavy on my stomach, I swallowed in my haste a ring which lay beneath the queen's window.' The servant instantly seized the duck by the neck, and carried it to the kitchen, and said to the cook, 'Kill this one, it is well fattened.' The cook weighed it in his hand, and said, 'Yes, it has not spared itself, and is fat enough to be roasted.' And he cut off its head, and as it was being drawn, the queen's ring was found inside it.

events.title: A Royal Pardon, a Humble Request, and a Lifesaving Act
detailed_summary: With the ring recovered from the duck, the servant was able to convincingly demonstrate his innocence.
The king, seeking to compensate for the injustice, granted the servant permission to ask for any favor, even offering him the most prestigious position in the royal court he might desire.
The servant, however, declined all offers of courtly advancement.
Instead, he requested only a horse and some money for travel, expressing a wish to see the world and journey a little.
His modest request was granted, and he embarked on his travels.
One day, his journey led him to a pond where he observed three fish ensnared in the reeds, gasping desperately for water.
Although fish are generally considered silent, he could hear them lamenting their imminent and miserable demise.
Possessing a compassionate nature, he dismounted his horse and carefully returned the three trapped fish to the water.
The fish, filled with joy at their rescue, surfaced, put their heads out of the water, and called out to him, promising to remember his deed and repay him for saving their lives.

events.title: An Inadvertent Threat and a Considerate Diversion
detailed_summary: The servant continued his journey on horseback.
After some time, he perceived a voice seemingly emanating from the sand at his feet.
He listened closely and understood it to be an ant-king complaining.

The ant-king lamented how people and their large animals carelessly disregarded ant colonies, specifically mentioning that the servant's 'stupid horse' was mercilessly trampling his ant subjects with its heavy hooves.
Upon hearing this, the servant immediately guided his horse onto a side path to avoid further disturbance to the ants.
The ant-king then called out to him, expressing gratitude and vowing that the ants would remember his considerate action, affirming the principle that one good deed begets another.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So he turned on to a side path and the ant-king cried out to him: ‘We will remember you—one good turn deserves another!’

events.title: A Sacrifice for the Starving Ravens
detailed_summary: The side path eventually led the servant into a dense wood.
There, he witnessed a scene where two parent ravens were standing by their nest and forcibly ejecting their young ones.
The old ravens cried out to their offspring, calling them idle and worthless, stating they could no longer provide food for them and that the young birds were now large enough to fend for themselves.
The poor young ravens, however, lay on the ground, feebly flapping their wings and crying out in distress.
They lamented their helplessness, acknowledging their inability to fly and their predicament of being left to starve.
Moved by their plight, the kind young man (the servant) dismounted, drew his sword, and killed his own horse.
He then offered the horse's carcass to the starving young ravens as food.

The young ravens eagerly hopped towards the unexpected meal, ate until they were satisfied, and then cried out to him, promising to remember his sacrifice and repay his kindness, echoing the sentiment that one good turn deserves another.

We must shift for ourselves, and yet we cannot fly! What can we do, but lie here and starve?’ So the good young fellow alighted and killed his horse with his sword, and gave it to them for food. Then they came hopping up to it, satisfied their hunger, and cried: ‘We will remember you—one good turn deserves another!’

events.title: Arrival in the City and the Princess's Perilous Challenge
detailed_summary: Having sacrificed his horse, the young man now had to continue his journey on foot.
After walking a considerable distance, he arrived at a large city.
The city streets were filled with a great deal of noise and a large crowd of people.
A man on horseback rode through the streets, loudly proclaiming a message: the king's daughter was seeking a husband.
However, any man who wished to marry her first had to complete a formidable task.
The announcer also warned that failure to succeed in this task would result in the forfeiture of the suitor's life.
Many men had previously attempted the challenge but had all failed, losing their lives in the process.
Despite these grim accounts, when the youth saw the king's daughter, he was so struck by her immense beauty that all thoughts of danger vanished from his mind.
He went before the king and formally declared himself as a suitor for the princess's hand.
Subsequently, he was escorted to the seashore.
In his presence, a gold ring was cast into the sea.

The king then commanded him to retrieve this ring from the ocean floor, adding a dire warning: if he resurfaced without the ring, he would be repeatedly thrown back into the sea until he drowned among the waves.
All the onlookers felt sorrow for the handsome youth as they departed, leaving him isolated by the sea.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All the people grieved for the handsome youth; then they went away, leaving him alone by the sea.

events.text_segment:
And now he had to use his own legs, and when he had walked a long way, he came to a large city. There was a great noise and crowd in the streets, and a man rode up on horseback, crying aloud: ‘The king’s daughter wants a husband; but whoever seeks her hand must perform a hard task, and if he does not succeed he will forfeit his life.’ Many had already made the attempt, but in vain; nevertheless when the youth saw the king’s daughter he was so overcome by her great beauty that he forgot all danger, went before the king, and declared himself a suitor.
So he was led out to the sea, and a gold ring was thrown into it, before his eyes; then the king ordered him to fetch this ring up from the bottom of the sea, and added: ‘If you come up again without it you will be thrown in again and again until you perish amid the waves.’ All the people grieved for the handsome youth; then they went away, leaving him alone by the sea.

He decided then and there that he would present himself before the King and offer his service, come what may. He knew not how he would succeed, but he felt a strange resolve settle upon him.

events.title: The Fishes' Repayment: Retrieval of the Sunken Ring
detailed_summary: The youth stood on the shore, contemplating his seemingly impossible task and what course of action he should take.
As he pondered, he suddenly observed three fish swimming towards him through the water.
He recognized them as the very same three fish whose lives he had saved earlier by returning them to the pond.
The fish in the middle was holding a mussel in its mouth.
It approached the shore and deposited the mussel at the youth's feet.
The youth picked up the mussel and opened it.
Inside the shell, he discovered the gold ring that had been thrown into the sea.
Overcome with joy, he took the ring and went to the king, anticipating that he would now be granted the promised reward for completing the task.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Full of joy he took it to the king and expected that he would grant him the promised reward.

events.title: The Princess's Second Task and the Ants' Meticulous Aid
detailed_summary: However, when the proud princess observed that the youth was not her social equal in terms of birth or status, she looked down on him.
Despite his success with the first task, she demanded that he perform another one before she would consider him.
She descended into the royal garden and, with her own hands, scattered ten sacks full of millet-seed across the grass.
She then instructed the youth that all these seeds must be collected by the following morning before sunrise, with not a single grain left behind.
The youth sat down in the garden, deeply troubled, as he tried to figure out how he could possibly accomplish such a feat.
He could devise no solution and sat there in sorrow, awaiting the dawn which he believed would bring his execution.
But as the very first rays of sunlight touched the garden, he looked up and saw all ten sacks standing neatly side by side, completely full, and not one grain of millet was missing from them.
The ant-king had arrived during the night, accompanied by thousands upon thousands of ants.

These grateful creatures had diligently worked throughout the night, picking up every single millet-seed and carefully gathering them into the sacks, thereby repaying the youth for his earlier kindness.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The ant-king had come in the night with thousands and thousands of ants, and the grateful creatures had by great industry picked up all the millet-seed and gathered them into the sacks.

The ant-king had come in the night with thousands and thousands of ants, and the grateful creatures had by great industry picked up all the millet-seed and gathered them into the sacks.

events.title: The Final Quest for the Apple of Life and a Joyful Union
detailed_summary: Shortly thereafter, the king's daughter herself came down to the garden.
She was astounded to witness that the young man had successfully completed the difficult task she had assigned him.
Despite this, her proud heart was not yet won over, and she declared that although he had performed both tasks, he would not become her husband until he brought her an apple from the Tree of Life.

The youth had no knowledge of where the Tree of Life was located, but he set out on the quest anyway, prepared to walk indefinitely, as long as his legs could carry him, even though he held little hope of finding it.
After journeying through three different kingdoms, he arrived one evening in a wood and lay down beneath a tree to rest and sleep.
While resting, he heard a rustling sound in the branches above him, and a golden apple fell directly into his hand.
At that very moment, three ravens flew down to him and perched on his knee.
They identified themselves as the three young ravens whom he had saved from starvation.
They explained that once they had grown large and strong, they heard about his quest for the Golden Apple.
Consequently, they had flown across the sea to the very end of the world, where the Tree of Life stands, and had brought back the apple for him.
The youth, filled with immense joy, began his journey homeward.
He presented the Golden Apple to the king's beautiful daughter, who now had no further excuses to refuse him.
Together, they cut the Apple of Life in two and ate it.
Upon eating the apple, the princess's heart was filled with love for him, and they lived together in undisturbed happiness to a very old age.

chapters.chapter_title: THE WOLF AND THE SEVEN LITTLE KIDS

events.title: Mother Goat's Warning and Departure
detailed_summary: A mother goat, who deeply loved her seven young children, needed to go into the forest to find food.
She gathered all seven kids and warned them to be vigilant against the wolf.
She emphasized that if the wolf got inside, he would eat them completely—skin, hair, and all.
The mother explained that the wolf frequently used disguises but could be identified by his harsh voice and black feet.
The little kids assured their mother they would be very careful and told her she could leave without any worry.
Satisfied, the old goat bleated and left, feeling confident in her children's safety.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was once upon a time an old goat who had seven little kids, and loved them with all the love of a mother for her children.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then the old one bleated, and went on her way with an easy mind.

events.text_segment: There was once upon a time an old goat who had seven little kids, and loved them with all the love of a mother for her children. One day she wanted to go into the forest and fetch some food. So she called all seven to her and said: ‘Dear children, I have to go into the forest, be on your guard against the wolf; if he comes in, he will devour you all—skin, hair, and everything. The wretch often disguises himself, but you will know him at once by his rough voice and his black feet.’ The kids said: ‘Dear mother, we will take good care of ourselves; you may go away without any anxiety.’ Then the old one bleated, and went on her way with an easy mind.

events.title: The Wolf Deceives and Devours the Kids
detailed_summary: The deceitful wolf approached the house for the third time, knocked, and announced he was their dear mother, back from the forest with a gift for each of them.
The little kids requested to see his paws first to verify his identity.
He showed his whitened paws through the window.
Believing it was truly their mother because of the white paws, the kids opened the door.
To their horror, the wolf entered, causing them to scatter and try to hide.
One hid under the table, the second in the bed, the third in the stove, the fourth in the kitchen, the fifth in the cupboard, the sixth under the washing-bowl, and the seventh in the clock-case.
The wolf found them all without much effort and swallowed six of them one by one.
Only the youngest kid, hidden in the clock-case, was not found by the wolf.

events.title: Mother Goat's Return and Heartbreak
detailed_summary: Once the wolf had eaten his fill, he left, lay down under a tree in a nearby green meadow, and fell asleep.
Shortly thereafter, the mother goat returned from the forest.
She encountered a terrible sight: the house door was wide open.
The table, chairs, and benches were knocked over, the washing-bowl was smashed, and the bed covers were pulled off.
She searched for her children but could not find them anywhere.
She called each of them by name, but none answered.
Finally, when she called the youngest, a soft voice responded, saying, 'Dear mother, I am in the clock-case.'
She took the kid out, and he told her that the wolf had come and eaten all the others.
One can only imagine the extent of her weeping for her unfortunate children.

events.title: The Miraculous Rescue of the Swallowed Kids
detailed_summary: Eventually, in her deep sorrow, she went outside, and the youngest kid accompanied her.
When they reached the meadow, they saw the wolf lying by the tree, snoring so loudly that the branches shook.
She examined him from all angles and noticed movement and struggling within his swollen belly.
A hopeful thought struck her: 'Oh heavens, could my poor children, whom he swallowed for supper, still be alive?'
The youngest kid was then instructed to hurry home and fetch scissors, a needle, and thread.
The mother goat carefully cut open the sleeping monster's stomach.
She had barely made the first incision when one little kid poked its head out.
As she cut further, all six kids emerged one after another, all alive and unharmed because the greedy monster had swallowed them whole.
There was tremendous rejoicing; they hugged their dear mother and jumped around like a tailor at his wedding.
The mother then said, 'Now go find some large stones, and we will fill the wicked beast’s stomach with them while he is still asleep.'
The seven kids quickly gathered stones and filled the wolf's stomach with as many as they could fit.
The mother then sewed him up very quickly, so that he remained unaware and did not stir at all.

What rejoicing there was! They embraced their dear mother, and jumped like a tailor at his wedding. The mother, however, said: ‘Now go and look for some big stones, and we will fill the wicked beast’s stomach with them while he is still asleep.’ Then the seven kids dragged the stones thither with all speed, and put as many of them into this stomach as they could get in; and the mother sewed him up again in the greatest haste, so that he was not aware of anything and never once stirred.

events.title: The Wolf's Demise and Joyful Celebration
detailed_summary: When the wolf finally woke up after sleeping soundly, he got to his feet.
The stones in his stomach made him extremely thirsty, so he wanted to go to a well to drink.
However, as he began to walk and move, the stones in his stomach knocked against each other and rattled.
He then cried out, wondering what was rumbling and tumbling against his poor bones, thinking it was the six kids but feeling like big stones.
When he reached the well and bent over the water to drink, the heavy stones caused him to fall in, and he drowned miserably.
Upon seeing this, the seven kids ran to the spot, shouting joyfully, 'The wolf is dead! The wolf is dead!'
They danced with their mother in celebration around the well.

events.title: The Dwarf's Compassionate Interventions on the Journey
detailed_summary: Two princes, having become profligate and impoverished, found themselves unable to go back to their kingdom.
Their younger brother, a small and unassuming dwarf, embarked on a journey to find his lost siblings.
Upon their reunion, the elder brothers ridiculed the dwarf, doubting his capacity to navigate the world when they, supposedly wiser, had failed.
Despite the mockery, all three set out together and eventually reached an ant-hill.
The two older brothers intended to dismantle the ant-hill merely to observe the ants scurrying in panic with their eggs.
However, the little dwarf intervened, asking them to let the ants be and stating he would not permit them to disturb the creatures.
Continuing their journey, they arrived at a lake where numerous ducks were swimming.
The two brothers expressed a desire to capture and roast a pair of ducks.
Once more, the dwarf stepped in, pleading for the ducks' lives and insisting they should not be killed.
Their travels then led them to a bees' nest situated in a hollow tree, from which honey flowed abundantly down the trunk.
The elder brothers proposed starting a fire beneath the tree to eliminate the bees and seize their honey.
The dwarf again prevented their actions, asserting that the insects should be allowed to live and that he could not let them be burned.
