events.title: The Brothers' Reunion and Initial Skill Demonstrations
detailed_summary: Four years later, as agreed, the four brothers reconvened at the crossroads.
They greeted each other warmly and journeyed together to their father's home.
Upon arrival, they recounted their experiences and the unique crafts each had mastered.
One day, while sitting under a tall tree, their father expressed a desire to witness their skills.
He looked up and asked his second son, the star-gazer, to identify the number of eggs in a chaffinch's nest at the treetop.
The star-gazer used his glass, looked up, and confirmed there were five eggs.
The father then instructed his eldest son, the thief, to retrieve the eggs without alerting the bird sitting on them.
The thief skillfully climbed the tree and brought the five eggs to his father from under the unsuspecting bird, which remained undisturbed.
The father then placed one egg on each corner of a table and the fifth in the center, and directed the huntsman to slice all five eggs in two with a single shot.
The huntsman took his bow and, with one shot, accurately struck all five eggs as requested.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After the space of four years, at the time agreed upon, the four brothers met at the four cross-roads; and having welcomed each other, set off towards their father’s home, where they told him all that had happened to them, and how each had learned some craft.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The huntsman took up his bow, and at one shot struck all the five eggs as his father wished.

events.text_segment:
After the space of four years, at the time agreed upon, the four brothers met at the four cross-roads; and having welcomed each other, set off towards their father’s home, where they told him all that had happened to them, and how each had learned some craft.
Then, one day, as they were sitting before the house under a very high tree, the father said, ‘I should like to try what each of you can do in this way.’ So he looked up, and said to the second son, ‘At the top of this tree there is a chaffinch’s nest; tell me how many eggs there are in it.’ The star-gazer took his glass, looked up, and said, ‘Five.’ ‘Now,’ said the father to the eldest son, ‘take away the eggs without letting the bird that is sitting upon them and hatching them know anything of what you are doing.’ So the cunning thief climbed up the tree, and brought away to his father the five eggs from under the bird; and it never saw or felt what he was doing, but kept sitting on at its ease. Then the father took the eggs, and put one on each corner of the table, and the fifth in the middle, and said to the huntsman, ‘Cut all the eggs in two pieces at one shot.’ The huntsman took up his bow, and at one shot struck all the five eggs as his father wished.

events.title: The Tailor's Mending Feat and Father's Commendation
detailed_summary: The father then turned to the young tailor, instructing him to sew the fragmented eggs and the young birds within them back together so perfectly that the shot would seem to have caused no harm.
The tailor took his special needle and meticulously sewed the eggs as directed.
Once the tailor had finished, the thief was tasked with returning the mended eggs to the nest, placing them back under the bird without its knowledge.
The mother bird continued to incubate the eggs, and after a few days, they hatched.
The young birds emerged with only a small red line across their necks, indicating where the tailor had sewn them.
The old man praised his sons, acknowledging they had used their time well and learned valuable skills.
He admitted he was unsure which of them deserved a prize and expressed a wish that an opportunity would soon arise for them to apply their talents meaningfully.

‘Well done, sons!’ said the old man; ‘you have made good use of your time, and learnt something worth the knowing; but I am sure I do not know which ought to have the prize. Oh, that a time might soon come for you to turn your skill to some account!’

events.title: The Quest to Rescue the Abducted Princess
detailed_summary: Shortly thereafter, the country was in turmoil because the king's daughter had been abducted by a formidable dragon.
The grieving king proclaimed that whoever rescued her would receive her hand in marriage.
The four brothers recognized this as a chance to use their skills and agreed to attempt to free the princess.
The star-gazer used his special glass and quickly located the princess, announcing he could see her on a distant rock in the sea, with the dragon guarding her nearby.
He approached the king and requested a ship for himself and his brothers.
They sailed across the sea until they reached the location.
There, they found the princess on the rock as the star-gazer had described, with the dragon asleep, its head resting in her lap.
The huntsman expressed concern that shooting the dragon might also harm the beautiful princess.
The thief then declared he would use his skill, and he stealthily stole the princess from under the sleeping dragon so quietly that the beast continued snoring, unaware.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then I will try my skill,’ said the thief, and went and stole her away from under the dragon, so quietly and gently that the beast did not know it, but went on snoring.

Then the four brothers said to each other, ‘Here is a chance for us; let us try what we can do.’ And they agreed to see whether they could not set the princess free. ‘I will soon find out where she is, however,’ said the star-gazer, as he looked through his glass; and he soon cried out, ‘I see her afar off, sitting upon a rock in the sea, and I can spy the dragon close by, guarding her.’ Then he went to the king, and asked for a ship for himself and his brothers; and they sailed together over the sea, till they came to the right place. There they found the princess sitting, as the star-gazer had said, on the rock; and the dragon was lying asleep, with his head upon her lap. ‘I dare not shoot at him,’ said the huntsman, ‘for I should kill the beautiful young lady also.’ ‘Then I will try my skill,’ said the thief, and went and stole her away from under the dragon, so quietly and gently that the beast did not know it, but went on snoring.

events.title: Dragon's Pursuit, Defeat, and Miraculous Escape
detailed_summary: Filled with joy, they quickly carried the princess to their boat, intending to reach their ship.
However, the dragon soon awoke, discovered the princess was missing, and pursued them, roaring through the air.
As the dragon positioned itself above their boat, preparing to seize the princess, the huntsman aimed his bow and shot it directly through the heart, killing it instantly.
Despite their success, they faced new danger as the enormous beast, in its fall, capsized their boat, leaving them to swim in the open sea amidst a few planks.
The tailor then took his needle and, with a few large stitches, quickly joined some of the planks together to form a raft.
Sitting on this makeshift raft, he sailed around, gathered all the scattered pieces of the boat, and expertly tacked them together, swiftly repairing it.
They were then able to reach their ship and return home safely.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: and they then reached the ship and got home safe.

But when he got over the boat, and wanted to pounce upon them and carry off the princess, the huntsman took up his bow and shot him straight through the heart so that he fell down dead. They were still not safe; for he was such a great beast that in his fall he overset the boat, and they had to swim in the open sea upon a few planks. So the tailor took his needle, and with a few large stitches put some of the planks together; and he sat down upon these, and sailed about and gathered up all pieces of the boat; and then tacked them together so quickly that the boat was soon ready, and they then reached the ship and got home safe.

events.title: The Princess's Rescue, a Royal Dispute, and a Generous Reward
detailed_summary: Upon bringing the princess back to her father, there was widespread rejoicing.
The king announced to the four brothers that one of them would marry her, but they needed to decide amongst themselves who it would be.
This led to a quarrel among the brothers, each arguing their contribution was most vital.
The star-gazer contended that without him finding the princess, their skills would have been useless, so she should be his.
The thief countered that merely seeing her was insufficient if he hadn't stolen her from the dragon, claiming her for himself.
The huntsman asserted she was his because if he hadn't killed the dragon, it would have destroyed them all.
The tailor argued that if he hadn't repaired the boat, they all would have drowned, making her his by right.
The king intervened, acknowledging the validity of each claim.
He reasoned that since all four could not marry the princess, and because she was actually fond of someone else, it was best if none of them married her.
To compensate for their efforts and loss, he offered to give each of them half a kingdom as a reward for their skill.
The brothers agreed this resolution was preferable to continued quarreling or marrying an unwilling bride.
The king fulfilled his promise, granting each half a kingdom, and they lived contentedly, also taking care of their father, while the princess was ensured to be safe from future harm.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When they had brought home the princess to her father, there was great rejoicing; and he said to the four brothers, ‘One of you shall marry her, but you must settle amongst yourselves which it is to be.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And the king then gave to each half a kingdom, as he had said; and they lived very happily the rest of their days, and took good care of their father; and somebody took better care of the young lady, than to let either the dragon or one of the craftsmen have her again.

events.text_segment: When they had brought home the princess to her father, there was great rejoicing; and he said to the four brothers, ‘One of you shall marry her, but you must settle amongst yourselves which it is to be.’ Then there arose a quarrel between them; and the star-gazer said, ‘If I had not found the princess out, all your skill would have been of no use; therefore she ought to be mine.’ ‘Your seeing her would have been of no use,’ said the thief, ‘if I had not taken her away from the dragon; therefore she ought to be mine.’ ‘No, she is mine,’ said the huntsman; ‘for if I had not killed the dragon, he would, after all, have torn you and the princess into pieces.’ ‘And if I had not sewn the boat together again,’ said the tailor, ‘you would all have been drowned, therefore she is mine.’ Then the king put in a word, and said, ‘Each of you is right; and as all cannot have the young lady, the best way is for neither of you to have her: for the truth is, there is somebody she likes a great deal better. But to make up for your loss, I will give each of you, as a reward for his skill, half a kingdom.’ So the brothers agreed that this plan would be much better than either quarrelling or marrying a lady who had no mind to have them. And the king then gave to each half a kingdom, as he had said; and they lived very happily the rest of their days, and took good care of their father; and somebody took better care of the young lady, than to let either the dragon or one of the craftsmen have her again.

events.title: The Merchant's Promise and the Quest for a Rose
detailed_summary: A merchant, preparing for a journey, inquired about his three daughters' desires for gifts.
The eldest daughter wished for pearls, and the second daughter asked for jewels.
The youngest daughter, named Lily, requested her father bring her a rose.
The father acknowledged the challenge of finding a rose during winter but committed to trying for Lily, whom he described as his prettiest daughter and a lover of flowers.
After successfully acquiring pearls and jewels for his two eldest daughters, the merchant searched extensively but in vain for a rose.
His attempts to find a rose in gardens during winter were met with mockery, with people questioning if he expected roses to grow in snow.
This situation greatly distressed him, as Lily was his most cherished child.
While journeying home, contemplating what gift to bring Lily, he arrived at an impressive castle.
Surrounding the castle was a unique garden, with one section appearing to be in full summer bloom while the other was stark and snow-covered.
He considered this a fortunate discovery and instructed his servant to approach a beautiful rose bed within the garden and retrieve one of the finest flowers.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A merchant, who had three daughters, was once setting out upon a journey; but before he went he asked each daughter what gift he should bring back for her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘A lucky hit!’ said he, as he called to his servant, and told him to go to a beautiful bed of roses that was there, and bring him away one of the finest flowers.

events.text_segment:
A merchant, who had three daughters, was once setting out upon a journey; but before he went he asked each daughter what gift he should bring back for her. The eldest wished for pearls; the second for jewels; but the third, who was called Lily, said, ‘Dear father, bring me a rose.’ Now it was no easy task to find a rose, for it was the middle of winter; yet as she was his prettiest daughter, and was very fond of flowers, her father said he would try what he could do. So he kissed all three, and bid them goodbye.
And when the time came for him to go home, he had bought pearls and jewels for the two eldest, but he had sought everywhere in vain for the rose; and when he went into any garden and asked for such a thing, the people laughed at him, and asked him whether he thought roses grew in snow. This grieved him very much, for Lily was his dearest child; and as he was journeying home, thinking what he should bring her, he came to a fine castle; and around the castle was a garden, in one half of which it seemed to be summer-time and in the other half winter. On one side the finest flowers were in full bloom, and on the other everything looked dreary and buried in the snow. ‘A lucky hit!’ said he, as he called to his servant, and told him to go to a beautiful bed of roses that was there, and bring him away one of the finest flowers.

Now it was the middle of winter, and snow and ice were everywhere, so it seemed impossible to find a rose; but as she was his prettiest daughter, and was very fond of flowers, her father said he would try to find her one.

And when the time came for him to return, he had bought pearls and jewels for the two eldest, but though he had travelled through many lands, he could not find a rose for Lily. He searched in every garden, but in vain; and when he asked for one, the people laughed at him, and said, "Do you expect roses to grow in the snow?" This troubled him greatly, for Lily was his favourite child.

As he was journeying homewards, thinking what he should bring her instead, he came to a fine castle. Around it was a garden, in one half of which everything was in full bloom, as in the finest summer, and in the other half everything was stark and snow-covered, as in the deepest winter. "This is a lucky find!" thought he; and he told his servant to go into the garden and fetch him one of the finest roses from the beautiful bed he saw there.

events.title: The Lion's Bargain and Lily's Selfless Decision
detailed_summary: Upon securing the rose and attempting to leave, the merchant and his servant were suddenly confronted by a fierce lion.
The lion roared angrily, proclaiming that whoever had stolen his roses would be eaten alive.
The merchant pleaded for his life, stating he was unaware the garden belonged to the lion.

The lion declared that nothing could save the merchant's life unless he promised to give the lion whatever first greeted him upon his return home; agreeing to this would grant him his life and the rose for his daughter.
The merchant was hesitant, expressing his fear that it might be his youngest daughter, Lily, who loved him dearly and always ran to meet him.
The servant, greatly alarmed, suggested that perhaps only a cat or a dog would meet him first.
Ultimately, with a troubled conscience, the merchant relented, accepted the rose, and agreed to surrender to the lion whatever first met him on his return.
As he approached his home, his youngest and dearest daughter, Lily, was the first to meet him, running to kiss and welcome him, and her joy increased upon seeing the rose.
However, her father became deeply sorrowful and wept, explaining that he had acquired the flower at a steep price, having promised her to a wild lion who would tear her apart and consume her.
He recounted all that had transpired and insisted that she should not go, regardless of the consequences.
Lily, however, comforted her father, asserting that his given word must be honored.
She declared her intention to go to the lion and attempt to pacify him, hoping he might allow her to return home safely.
The following morning, she inquired about the route she needed to take, bid her father farewell, and set out courageously into the woods.

events.text_segment:
This done, they were riding away well pleased, when up sprang a fierce lion, and roared out, ‘Whoever has stolen my roses shall be eaten up alive!’ Then the man said, ‘I knew not that the garden belonged to you; can nothing save my life?’ ‘No!’ said the lion, ‘nothing, unless you undertake to give me whatever meets you on your return home; if you agree to this, I will give you your life, and the rose too for your daughter.’ But the man was unwilling to do so and said, ‘It may be my youngest daughter, who loves me most, and always runs to meet me when I go home.’ Then the servant was greatly frightened, and said, ‘It may perhaps be only a cat or a dog.’ And at last the man yielded with a heavy heart, and took the rose; and said he would give the lion whatever should meet him first on his return.
And as he came near home, it was Lily, his youngest and dearest daughter, that met him; she came running, and kissed him, and welcomed him home; and when she saw that he had brought her the rose, she was still more glad. But her father began to be very sorrowful, and to weep, saying, ‘Alas, my dearest child! I have bought this flower at a high price, for I have said I would give you to a wild lion; and when he has you, he will tear you in pieces, and eat you.’ Then he told her all that had happened, and said she should not go, let what would happen.
But she comforted him, and said, ‘Dear father, the word you have given must be kept; I will go to the lion, and soothe him: perhaps he will let me come safe home again.’
The next morning she asked the way she was to go, and took leave of her father, and went forth with a bold heart into the wood.

events.title: Marriage to the Enchanted Prince and a Joyful Family Reunion
detailed_summary: It was revealed that the lion was, in fact, an enchanted prince.
By day, he and his entire court were transformed into lions, but in the evening, they regained their human forms.
When Lily arrived at the castle, the prince received her with such politeness and charm that she agreed to marry him.
A wedding feast was held, and they coexisted happily for a significant period.

The prince was only visible in his human state once evening arrived, at which time he would conduct his court; however, every morning, he would leave his bride and depart alone, his destination unknown to her until nightfall.
After some time had passed, he informed Lily that a grand feast was scheduled at her father's house the next day for her eldest sister's wedding.
He offered that if she wished to attend and visit her sister, his lions would escort her there.
Lily was greatly cheered by the thought of seeing her father again.
Upon her arrival, everyone was overjoyed to see her, as they had long believed her to be deceased.
She reassured them of her current happiness, stayed until the feast concluded, and then returned to the woods.

events.text_segment:
But the lion was an enchanted prince. By day he and all his court were lions, but in the evening they took their right forms again. And when Lily came to the castle, he welcomed her so courteously that she agreed to marry him. The wedding-feast was held, and they lived happily together a long time. The prince was only to be seen as soon as evening came, and then he held his court; but every morning he left his bride, and went away by himself, she knew not whither, till the night came again.
After some time he said to her, ‘Tomorrow there will be a great feast in your father’s house, for your eldest sister is to be married; and if you wish to go and visit her my lions shall lead you thither.’ Then she rejoiced much at the thoughts of seeing her father once more, and set out with the lions; and everyone was overjoyed to see her, for they had thought her dead long since. But she told them how happy she was, and stayed till the feast was over, and then went back to the wood.

events.title: A Forbidden Wish and the Prince's Transformation into a Dove
detailed_summary: Shortly thereafter, Lily's second sister was to be married, and Lily received an invitation to the wedding.
This time, she insisted to the prince that she would not go alone and that he must accompany her.
The prince was unwilling, warning her that such an action would be extremely perilous.

He explained that if even the slightest gleam from a torchlight were to fall upon him, his enchantment would intensify, causing him to transform into a dove and compelling him to wander the world for seven long years.
Despite his warnings, Lily persisted, giving him no peace and assuring him she would exercise caution to prevent any light from reaching him.
Eventually, they set out together, taking their young child with them.
For his protection, she selected a large hall with substantial, thick walls for him to remain in while the wedding torches were lit.
Regrettably, no one noticed a small crack present in the door of the hall.

The wedding ceremony was conducted with great splendor. However, as the procession returned from the church, passing by the hall with their torches, a very small ray of light fell upon the prince through the crack.
In an instant, he disappeared. When his wife entered the hall and searched for him, she found only a white dove.

The dove communicated to her that he was condemned to fly across the face of the earth for seven years, but he would intermittently release a white feather to indicate his path, enabling her to follow him with the hope of eventually overtaking him and securing his freedom.

events.text_segment: Her second sister was soon after married, and when Lily was asked to go to the wedding, she said to the prince, ‘I will not go alone this time—you must go with me.’ But he would not, and said that it would be a very hazardous thing; for if the least ray of the torch-light should fall upon him his enchantment would become still worse, for he should be changed into a dove, and be forced to wander about the world for seven long years. However, she gave him no rest, and said she would take care no light should fall upon him. So at last they set out together, and took with them their little child; and she chose a large hall with thick walls for him to sit in while the wedding-torches were lighted; but, unluckily, no one saw that there was a crack in the door. Then the wedding was held with great pomp, but as the train came from the church, and passed with the torches before the hall, a very small ray of light fell upon the prince. In a moment he disappeared, and when his wife came in and looked for him, she found only a white dove; and it said to her, ‘Seven years must I fly up and down over the face of the earth, but every now and then I will let fall a white feather, that will show you the way I am going; follow it, and at last you may overtake and set me free.’

events.title: Lily's Seven-Year Ordeal and Celestial Assistance
detailed_summary: Following his statement, the prince, now a dove, flew out the door, and poor Lily began her pursuit, guided intermittently by a falling white feather that indicated her route.
In this manner, she roamed continuously through the vast world, never looking aside or taking any rest for a period of seven years.
As the seven-year mark approached, she started to feel glad, believing her troubles were nearing an end; yet, relief was still distant.
One day, while traveling, she realized she had missed the white feather, and upon looking up, she could no longer see the dove anywhere.
She thought to herself that no human assistance could now be of use to her.
So, she approached the Sun, explaining its universal reach, and asked if it had seen her white dove.
The Sun replied that it had not seen the dove but offered her a casket, instructing her to open it when her hour of need arrived.
Lily thanked the Sun and continued her journey until evening.
When the Moon rose, she cried out to it, describing its nightly illumination, and asked if it had seen her white dove.
The Moon responded that it could not help her but would give her an egg, advising her to break it when the need arose.
She thanked the Moon and journeyed on until the night-wind began to blow.
She addressed the Night-Wind, noting its pervasive presence, and asked if it had seen her white dove.
The Night-Wind replied that it had not but would consult three other winds.
The East Wind and West Wind subsequently reported they had not seen the dove either.
However, the South Wind stated it had seen the white dove, revealing he had flown to the Red Sea and transformed back into a lion, as the seven years had passed.
The South Wind added that the lion was currently fighting a dragon, which was an enchanted princess attempting to separate him from Lily.
The Night-Wind then offered counsel: Lily should go to the Red Sea, where on the right shore she would find many rods. She was to count them, break off the eleventh, and strike the dragon with it.
This act would grant the lion victory, and both he and the dragon would revert to their true forms.
Afterward, she should look for a griffin by the Red Sea, jump onto its back with her beloved as quickly as possible, and it would transport them across the waters to their home.

The Night-Wind also gave her a nut, instructing her to throw it down when they were halfway across the sea. This would cause a tall nut-tree to spring from the waters, allowing the griffin to rest, as it would otherwise lack the strength for the entire journey; forgetting this would result in them both falling into the sea.

events.text_segment:
This said, he flew out at the door, and poor Lily followed; and every now and then a white feather fell, and showed her the way she was to journey. Thus she went roving on through the wide world, and looked neither to the right hand nor to the left, nor took any rest, for seven years. Then she began to be glad, and thought to herself that the time was fast coming when all her troubles should end; yet repose was still far off, for one day as she was travelling on she missed the white feather, and when she lifted up her eyes she could nowhere see the dove. ‘Now,’ thought she to herself, ‘no aid of man can be of use to me.’ So she went to the sun and said, ‘Thou shinest everywhere, on the hill’s top and the valley’s depth—hast thou anywhere seen my white dove?’ ‘No,’ said the sun, ‘I have not seen it; but I will give thee a casket—open it when thy hour of need comes.’
So she thanked the sun, and went on her way till eventide; and when the moon arose, she cried unto it, and said, ‘Thou shinest through the night, over field and grove—hast thou nowhere seen my white dove?’ ‘No,’ said the moon, ‘I cannot help thee but I will give thee an egg—break it when need comes.’
Then she thanked the moon, and went on till the night-wind blew; and she raised up her voice to it, and said, ‘Thou blowest through every tree and under every leaf—hast thou not seen my white dove?’ ‘No,’ said the night-wind, ‘but I will ask three other winds; perhaps they have seen it.’ Then the east wind and the west wind came, and said they too had not seen it, but the south wind said, ‘I have seen the white dove—he has fled to the Red Sea, and is changed once more into a lion, for the seven years are passed away, and there he is fighting with a dragon; and the dragon is an enchanted princess, who seeks to separate him from you.’ Then the night-wind said, ‘I will give thee counsel. Go to the Red Sea; on the right shore stand many rods—count them, and when thou comest to the eleventh, break it off, and smite the dragon with it; and so the lion will have the victory, and both of them will appear to you in their own forms. Then look round and thou wilt see a griffin, winged like bird, sitting by the Red Sea; jump on to his back with thy beloved one as quickly as possible, and he will carry you over the waters to your home. I will also give thee this nut,’ continued the night-wind. ‘When you are half-way over, throw it down, and out of the waters will immediately spring up a high nut-tree on which the griffin will be able to rest, otherwise he would not have the strength to bear you the whole way; if, therefore, thou dost forget to throw down the nut, he will let you both fall into the sea.’

events.title: Victory, Betrayal at the Red Sea, and Lily's Unwavering Resolve
detailed_summary: The desolate wanderer proceeded and discovered that all the details provided by the Night-Wind were accurate.
She located the rods, selected the eleventh one, and struck the dragon with it.
Immediately, the lion transformed back into a prince, and the dragon reverted to her form as a princess.
However, the moment the princess was freed from the enchantment, she grabbed the prince by his arm, leaped onto the griffin's back, and departed, carrying the prince away with her.
Thus, the unfortunate traveler found herself once again abandoned and forlorn.
Despite this, she mustered her courage and declared that as far as the wind blew and as long as roosters crowed, she would continue her journey until she found him again.
She traveled for an extensive period until she eventually reached the castle to which the princess had transported the prince.
Upon her arrival, she observed that a feast was being prepared and learned that the wedding was soon to take place.

So our poor wanderer went forth, and found all as the night-wind had said; and she plucked the eleventh rod, and smote the dragon, and the lion forthwith became a prince, and the dragon a princess again. But no sooner was the princess released from the spell, than she seized the prince by the arm and sprang on to the griffin’s back, and went off carrying the prince away with her.
Thus the unhappy traveller was again forsaken and forlorn; but she took heart and said, ‘As far as the wind blows, and so long as the cock crows, I will journey on, till I find him once again.’ She went on for a long, long way, till at length she came to the castle whither the princess had carried the prince; and there was a feast got ready, and she heard that the wedding was about to be held.

events.title: Magical Gifts, Deception, and the Prince's Miraculous Awakening
detailed_summary: Lily, invoking heavenly aid, took the casket given to her by the Sun and discovered within it a dress as radiant as the sun itself.
She put on the dress and entered the palace, where all the people gazed at her in admiration.
The dazzling dress greatly pleased the bride (the princess), who inquired if it was for sale.
Lily replied that it was not available for gold and silver, but rather for 'flesh and blood'.
When the princess asked for clarification, Lily requested permission to speak with the bridegroom in his chamber that night, offering the dress in exchange.
The princess eventually consented but secretly instructed her chamberlain to administer a sleeping draught to the prince to ensure he would neither hear nor see Lily.
When evening arrived and the prince had fallen asleep, Lily was escorted into his chamber.

She sat at his feet and spoke of her seven-year pursuit, her consultations with the sun, moon, and night-wind, and her role in helping him defeat the dragon, questioning if he would then completely forget her.
However, the prince remained so soundly asleep that her voice merely passed over him, resembling the sound of wind whistling through fir-trees.
Poor Lily was then led away and compelled to surrender the golden dress.
Realizing there was no immediate help for her, she went into a meadow, sat down, and wept.
While seated there, she remembered the egg given to her by the Moon.
Upon breaking it, a hen and twelve chickens made of pure gold emerged, played about, and then nestled under the hen's wings, creating a most beautiful spectacle.
She rose and guided them before her until the bride saw them from her window.
The sight so pleased the princess that she came out and asked Lily if she would sell the brood.
Lily responded with the same terms: 'Not for gold or silver, but for flesh and blood: let me again this evening speak with the bridegroom in his chamber, and I will give thee the whole brood.'
The princess, intending to deceive Lily as before, agreed to her request.
However, when the prince retired to his chamber, he asked the chamberlain why the wind had whistled so strangely during the night.

The chamberlain then revealed everything: how he had administered a sleeping draught to the prince, how a poor maiden had come and spoken to him in his chamber, and that she was scheduled to return again that night.
Consequently, the prince made sure to discard the sleeping draught.
When Lily arrived and began once more to recount the sorrows that had befallen her and how faithful and true she had remained to him, he recognized the voice of his beloved wife.

He sprang up, exclaiming that she had awakened him as if from a dream, explaining that the strange princess had cast a spell upon him, causing him to forget her entirely, but that Heaven had providentially sent Lily to him at a fortunate moment.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then the prince took care to throw away the sleeping draught; and when Lily came and began again to tell him what woes had befallen her, and how faithful and true to him she had been, he knew his beloved wife’s voice, and sprang up, and said, ‘You have awakened me as from a dream, for the strange princess had thrown a spell around me, so that I had altogether forgotten you; but Heaven hath sent you to me in a lucky hour.’

events.text_segment:
‘Heaven aid me now!’ said she; and she took the casket that the sun had given her, and found that within it lay a dress as dazzling as the sun itself. So she put it on, and went into the palace, and all the people gazed upon her; and the dress pleased the bride so much that she asked whether it was to be sold. ‘Not for gold and silver.’ said she, ‘but for flesh and blood.’ The princess asked what she meant, and she said, ‘Let me speak with the bridegroom this night in his chamber, and I will give thee the dress.’ At last the princess agreed, but she told her chamberlain to give the prince a sleeping draught, that he might not hear or see her. When evening came, and the prince had fallen asleep, she was led into his chamber, and she sat herself down at his feet, and said: ‘I have followed thee seven years. I have been to the sun, the moon, and the night-wind, to seek thee, and at last I have helped thee to overcome the dragon. Wilt thou then forget me quite?’ But the prince all the time slept so soundly, that her voice only passed over him, and seemed like the whistling of the wind among the fir-trees.
Then poor Lily was led away, and forced to give up the golden dress; and when she saw that there was no help for her, she went out into a meadow, and sat herself down and wept. But as she sat she bethought herself of the egg that the moon had given her; and when she broke it, there ran out a hen and twelve chickens of pure gold, that played about, and then nestled under the old one’s wings, so as to form the most beautiful sight in the world. And she rose up and drove them before her, till the bride saw them from her window, and was so pleased that she came forth and asked her if she would sell the brood. ‘Not for gold or silver, but for flesh and blood: let me again this evening speak with the bridegroom in his chamber, and I will give thee the whole brood.’
Then the princess thought to betray her as before, and agreed to what she asked: but when the prince went to his chamber he asked the chamberlain why the wind had whistled so in the night. And the chamberlain told him all—how he had given him a sleeping draught, and how a poor maiden had come and spoken to him in his chamber, and was to come again that night. Then the prince took care to throw away the sleeping draught; and when Lily came and began again to tell him what woes had befallen her, and how faithful and true to him she had been, he knew his beloved wife’s voice, and sprang up, and said, ‘You have awakened me as from a dream, for the strange princess had thrown a spell around me, so that I had altogether forgotten you; but Heaven hath sent you to me in a lucky hour.’

events.title: Daring Escape and a Joyful Ever After
detailed_summary: Unobserved, they secretly departed from the palace during the night.
They positioned themselves on the griffin, which then flew back with them across the Red Sea.
When they reached the midpoint of their journey over the water, Lily dropped the nut into the sea.
Instantly, a large nut-tree emerged from the water, providing a place for the griffin to rest for a while.
After its rest, the griffin safely transported them to their home.
There, they found their child, who had grown to be comely and fair.
Following all the trials and tribulations they had endured, they lived together in happiness for the remainder of their days.

events.title: The Farmer's Ungrateful Dismissal of His Loyal Horse
detailed_summary: A farmer possessed a horse that had served him with great loyalty and effectiveness over many years.
As the horse aged and became incapable of working, the farmer decided he would no longer provide it with food.
The farmer informed the horse that it was no longer needed and must leave the stable.
He set a seemingly impossible condition for the horse's return: it had to demonstrate strength greater than a lion.
After stating this, the farmer opened the stable door and cast the horse out.

detailed_summary: The banished horse felt profound sadness and roamed through the woods, searching for minimal protection from the inclement weather.
A fox encountered the horse, observed its dejected demeanor, and asked why it appeared so lonely and sorrowful.

events.text_segment: The poor horse was very melancholy, and wandered up and down in the wood, seeking some little shelter from the cold wind and rain. Presently a fox met him: ‘What’s the matter, my friend?’ said he, ‘why do you hang down your head and look so lonely and woe-begone?’ ‘Ah!’ replied the horse, ‘justice and avarice never dwell in one house; my master has forgotten all that I have done for him so many years, and because I can no longer work he has turned me adrift, and says unless I become stronger than a lion he will not take me back again; what chance can I have of that? he knows I have none, or he would not talk so.’

When the work was done, the fox clapped the horse on the shoulder, and said, ‘Jip! Dobbin! Jip!’ Then up he sprang, and moved off, dragging the lion behind him. The beast began to roar and bellow, till all the birds of the wood flew away for fright; but the horse let him sing on, and made his way quietly over the fields to his master’s house.
‘Here he is, master,’ said he, ‘I have got the better of him’: and when the farmer saw his old servant, his heart relented, and he said. ‘Thou shalt stay in thy stable and be well taken care of.’ And so the poor old horse had plenty to eat, and lived—till he died.

events.title: The Soldier's Dismissal and the Witch's Treacherous Demands
detailed_summary: A soldier, after years of faithful service, was dismissed by the king without pension due to his war wounds making him unfit for further service.
Distraught and unsure how to make a living, he wandered into a forest and sought shelter at a witch's house.
The witch offered him food and lodging for a night if he would perform a task for her.
His first task was to dig her entire garden the next day. He worked diligently but could not complete it in one day.
The witch allowed him to stay another night, and for this, he had to chop a load of wood small, which he accomplished.
For a third night's stay, the witch asked him to retrieve her fallen blue light from an old dry well behind her house, a light that burned blue and never extinguished.
The next day, the witch lowered him into the well in a basket. He found the blue light and signaled to be pulled up.
As he neared the top, the witch reached to take the blue light, but the soldier, suspecting her ill intent, refused to give it to her until he was safely on solid ground.
Enraged, the witch let him fall back into the well and departed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was once upon a time a soldier who for many years had served the king faithfully, but when the war came to an end could serve no longer because of the many wounds which he had received.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The witch fell into a passion, let him fall again into the well, and went away.

events.text_segment: There was once upon a time a soldier who for many years had served the king faithfully, but when the war came to an end could serve no longer because of the many wounds which he had received. The king said to him: ‘You may return to your home, I need you no longer, and you will not receive any more money, for he only receives wages who renders me service for them.’ Then the soldier did not know how to earn a living, went away greatly troubled, and walked the whole day, until in the evening he entered a forest. When darkness came on, he saw a light, which he went up to, and came to a house wherein lived a witch. ‘Do give me one night’s lodging, and a little to eat and drink,’ said he to her, ‘or I shall starve.’ ‘Oho!’ she answered, ‘who gives anything to a run-away soldier? Yet will I be compassionate, and take you in, if you will do what I wish.’ ‘What do you wish?’ said the soldier. ‘That you should dig all round my garden for me, tomorrow.’ The soldier consented, and next day laboured with all his strength, but could not finish it by the evening. ‘I see well enough,’ said the witch, ‘that you can do no more today, but I will keep you yet another night, in payment for which you must tomorrow chop me a load of wood, and chop it small.’ The soldier spent the whole day in doing it, and in the evening the witch proposed that he should stay one night more. ‘Tomorrow, you shall only do me a very trifling piece of work. Behind my house, there is an old dry well, into which my light has fallen, it burns blue, and never goes out, and you shall bring it up again.’ Next day the old woman took him to the well, and let him down in a basket. He found the blue light, and made her a signal to draw him up again. She did draw him up, but when he came near the edge, she stretched down her hand and wanted to take the blue light away from him. ‘No,’ said he, perceiving her evil intention, ‘I will not give you the light until I am standing with both feet upon the ground.’ The witch fell into a passion, let him fall again into the well, and went away.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: There was once upon a time a soldier who for many years had served the king faithfully, but when the war came to an end could serve no longer because of the many wounds which he had received. It was now quite dark, so he looked about for a lodging, but found none. At length he saw a light, and went towards it, and came to a house in which lived an old witch. He knocked, and she opened the door and asked what he wanted. He answered, he was a poor soldier, and begged for a night's lodging. She said, 'If you will do what I wish, I will take you in. To-morrow morning you must dig my garden for me, and make it all neat.' The soldier agreed, and the next day he worked with all his strength, but could not finish it by the evening. The witch said, 'I see you are not able to do anything more to-day, but I will keep you here another night. To-morrow you must chop me a load of wood small.' The soldier spent the whole day at this work, and in the evening the witch said, 'You have been very active, and I will keep you here one night more. She did so, but when he was near the top, she stretched out her hand to take the blue light away from him. The soldier saw her evil intention, and said, 'No, I will not give you the light until I am standing with both feet on the ground.' The witch was very angry, and let him fall back into the well, and went away, leaving the poor soldier at the bottom.

events.title: Discovery of the Blue Light's Power and Retribution Against the Witch
detailed_summary: The soldier landed unharmed on the moist ground of the well, the blue light still burning, but he despaired, seeing no way to escape death.
He found his tobacco pipe, still half-full, and decided to have a final smoke, lighting it with the blue light.
As the smoke swirled, a small black dwarf suddenly appeared and asked what the soldier commanded.
The soldier, astonished, learned that the dwarf was obligated to obey all his orders.
His first command was for the dwarf to help him out of the well.
The dwarf took his hand and led him through an underground passage, ensuring the soldier brought the blue light with him.
Along the way, the dwarf showed him the witch's hidden treasures, and the soldier took as much gold as he could carry.
Once above ground, the soldier ordered the dwarf to bind the old witch and take her before the judge.
Shortly, the witch was seen riding a wild tom-cat, screaming, and soon after, the dwarf returned, reporting that the witch was hanged.
The dwarf explained that he would appear instantly if the soldier lit his pipe with the blue light, and then vanished.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The poor soldier fell without injury on the moist ground, and the blue light went on burning, but of what use was that to him?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Thereupon he vanished from his sight.

events.text_segment: The poor soldier fell without injury on the moist ground, and the blue light went on burning, but of what use was that to him? He saw very well that he could not escape death. He sat for a while very sorrowfully, then suddenly he felt in his pocket and found his tobacco pipe, which was still half full. ‘This shall be my last pleasure,’ thought he, pulled it out, lit it at the blue light and began to smoke. When the smoke had circled about the cavern, suddenly a little black dwarf stood before him, and said: ‘Lord, what are your commands?’ ‘What my commands are?’ replied the soldier, quite astonished. ‘I must do everything you bid me,’ said the little man. ‘Good,’ said the soldier; ‘then in the first place help me out of this well.’ The little man took him by the hand, and led him through an underground passage, but he did not forget to take the blue light with him. On the way the dwarf showed him the treasures which the witch had collected and hidden there, and the soldier took as much gold as he could carry. When he was above, he said to the little man: ‘Now go and bind the old witch, and carry her before the judge.’ In a short time she came by like the wind, riding on a wild tom-cat and screaming frightfully. Nor was it long before the little man reappeared. ‘It is all done,’ said he, ‘and the witch is already hanging on the gallows. What further commands has my lord?’ inquired the dwarf. ‘At this moment, none,’ answered the soldier; ‘you can return home, only be at hand immediately, if I summon you.’ ‘Nothing more is needed than that you should light your pipe at the blue light, and I will appear before you at once.’ Thereupon he vanished from his sight.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The poor soldier fell without injury on the moist ground, and the blue light went on burning, but of what use was that to him? He saw well enough that he must die, for he could not get out. His pipe was still whole, and he had a little tobacco left in it, so he said, "I will smoke one last pipe, and then die." He took it out, and lit it at the blue light, and as he was doing so, a little black dwarf stood suddenly before him, and asked, "What are your commands, master?" "What commands have I?" replied the soldier, "I have nothing to command." "I am bound to obey you in everything," said the dwarf, "as the old witch from whom you took the light bound me. Whatever you wish, that shall you have, whether it be gold or silver, or castles, or anything of the kind." "Good," said the soldier, who was not sorry to hear this, "then in the first place, help me out of this well." The dwarf took him by the hand, and led him through an underground passage, but he did not forget to take the blue light with him. On the way, the dwarf showed him the treasures which the witch had secretly laid up, and which consisted of heaps of gold and silver. The soldier took as much of it as he could carry, and when they got above ground, he said to the dwarf, "Now take me to the place where the old witch lives." "That is not necessary," said the dwarf, "she has already received her deserts; the other day, when she was riding away on her broomstick, she was not able to get on, and fell down and broke her neck." "Then," said the soldier, "bind her fast, and carry her before the judge." Shortly afterwards, the dwarf was seen riding on a wild tom-cat, at a furious pace, and the old witch was bound on the back of it, and was screaming fearfully. Soon after, the dwarf came back, and said, "She is hanged, and the judge has given her house and all her property to you." The soldier was very glad of this, and said, "If you will appear to me whenever I light my pipe at the blue light, you may go." The dwarf vanished, and the soldier went to the witch's house.

events.title: The Soldier's Revenge Begins: The Princess Enslaved
detailed_summary: The soldier returned to the town he had come from.
He went to the best inn, ordered fine clothes, and instructed the landlord to prepare the most handsome room possible.
After settling in, he summoned the little black manikin using the blue light.
He expressed his desire for revenge against the king who had dismissed him and left him to hunger.
He commanded the manikin to bring the king's daughter to him in her sleep, to perform servant's work.
The manikin stated it was an easy task for him but warned the soldier of the grave danger if this act was discovered.
At midnight, the door opened, and the manikin carried in the sleeping princess.
The soldier immediately ordered her to fetch a broom and sweep the chamber.
After she completed this, he had her come to his chair, stretched out his feet, and ordered her to pull off his boots, then threw them in her face, making her pick them up, clean, and brighten them.
The princess performed all his commands without opposition, silently and with half-closed eyes.
When the first cock crowed, the manikin transported her back to the royal palace and laid her in her bed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The soldier returned to the town from which he came.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When the first cock crowed, the manikin carried her back to the royal palace, and laid her in her bed.

events.text_segment: The soldier returned to the town from which he came. He went to the best inn, ordered himself handsome clothes, and then bade the landlord furnish him a room as handsome as possible. When it was ready and the soldier had taken possession of it, he summoned the little black manikin and said: ‘I have served the king faithfully, but he has dismissed me, and left me to hunger, and now I want to take my revenge.’ ‘What am I to do?’ asked the little man. ‘Late at night, when the king’s daughter is in bed, bring her here in her sleep, she shall do servant’s work for me.’ The manikin said: ‘That is an easy thing for me to do, but a very dangerous thing for you, for if it is discovered, you will fare ill.’ When twelve o’clock had struck, the door sprang open, and the manikin carried in the princess. ‘Aha! are you there?’ cried the soldier, ‘get to your work at once! Fetch the broom and sweep the chamber.’ When she had done this, he ordered her to come to his chair, and then he stretched out his feet and said: ‘Pull off my boots,’ and then he threw them in her face, and made her pick them up again, and clean and brighten them. She, however, did everything he bade her, without opposition, silently and with half-shut eyes. When the first cock crowed, the manikin carried her back to the royal palace, and laid her in her bed.

events.title: The King's Pea Trail Plan and the Manikin's Cunning Countermeasure
detailed_summary: The next morning, the princess went to her father, the king, and recounted a very strange dream.
She described being carried through the streets with lightning speed to a soldier's room, where she had to serve him like a servant, sweeping, cleaning boots, and doing other menial tasks.
She remarked that although it was a dream, she felt as tired as if she had actually done everything.
The king suspected the dream might be true and advised her to fill her pocket with peas and make a small hole in it, so if she were carried away again, the peas would leave a trail.
Unseen by the king, the manikin was nearby and overheard this plan.
That night, when the sleeping princess was again carried through the streets, some peas did fall from her pocket.
However, they created no track because the crafty manikin had earlier scattered peas in every street.
The princess was again forced to perform servant's work until cock-crow.

events.text_segment: Next morning when the princess arose she went to her father, and told him that she had had a very strange dream. ‘I was carried through the streets with the rapidity of lightning,’ said she, ‘and taken into a soldier’s room, and I had to wait upon him like a servant, sweep his room, clean his boots, and do all kinds of menial work. It was only a dream, and yet I am just as tired as if I really had done everything.’ ‘The dream may have been true,’ said the king. ‘I will give you a piece of advice. Fill your pocket full of peas, and make a small hole in the pocket, and then if you are carried away again, they will fall out and leave a track in the streets.’ But unseen by the king, the manikin was standing beside him when he said that, and heard all. At night when the sleeping princess was again carried through the streets, some peas certainly did fall out of her pocket, but they made no track, for the crafty manikin had just before scattered peas in every street there was. And again the princess was compelled to do servant’s work until cock-crow.

events.title: The Hidden Shoe Plot Succeeds: The Soldier's Capture and Imprisonment
detailed_summary: The following morning, the king sent his people to find the pea trail, but it was to no avail; poor children were found in every street picking up peas, believing it had rained peas.
The king then devised a new plan: the princess was to keep her shoes on in bed and, before returning from wherever she was taken, hide one of them there, which he would then find.
The black manikin overheard this plot and informed the soldier when he was again ordered to bring the princess.
The manikin warned the soldier that he knew no way to counteract this strategy and that if the shoe were found in the soldier's house, it would mean trouble for him.
The soldier, unperturbed, instructed the manikin to proceed as ordered.
For a third night, the princess was forced to work like a servant, but before she left, she hid her shoe under the soldier's bed.
The next morning, the king had the entire town searched for his daughter's shoe.
It was found at the soldier's residence, and the soldier, who had briefly stepped outside the gate at the dwarf's suggestion, was quickly apprehended and imprisoned.
In his attempted flight, he had forgotten his most valuable possessions—the blue light and the gold—and only had a single ducat in his pocket.

events.text_segment:
Next morning the king sent his people out to seek the track, but it was all in vain, for in every street poor children were sitting, picking up peas, and saying: ‘It must have rained peas, last night.’ ‘We must think of something else,’ said the king; ‘keep your shoes on when you go to bed, and before you come back from the place where you are taken, hide one of them there, I will soon contrive to find it.’ The black manikin heard this plot, and at night when the soldier again ordered him to bring the princess, revealed it to him, and told him that he knew of no expedient to counteract this stratagem, and that if the shoe were found in the soldier’s house it would go badly with him. ‘Do what I bid you,’ replied the soldier, and again this third night the princess was obliged to work like a servant, but before she went away, she hid her shoe under the bed.
Next morning the king had the entire town searched for his daughter’s shoe. It was found at the soldier’s, and the soldier himself, who at the entreaty of the dwarf had gone outside the gate, was soon brought back, and thrown into prison. In his flight he had forgotten the most valuable things he had, the blue light and the gold, and had only one ducat in his pocket.

events.title: The Soldier's Final Plea, The Manikin's Intervention, and Ultimate Triumph
detailed_summary: Chained in his dungeon, the soldier saw a former comrade pass by his window.
He tapped on the glass, and when the man approached, the soldier asked him to fetch a small bundle he had left at the inn, offering a ducat for this service.
His comrade retrieved the bundle and brought it to him.
Once alone, the soldier lit his pipe with the blue light, summoning the black manikin.
The manikin told his master not to fear, to go wherever they took him, and to ensure he had the blue light with him.
The next day, the soldier was tried and, despite having done nothing wicked in the conventional sense, was condemned to death by the judge.
As he was led to his execution, he begged a last favor from the king: to be allowed to smoke one more pipe on his way.
The king granted him permission to smoke three pipes but stated this would not spare his life.
The soldier pulled out his pipe, lit it at the blue light, and as smoke wreaths ascended, the manikin appeared with a small cudgel, asking for commands.
The soldier ordered him to strike down the false judge, his constable, and not to spare the king who had treated him so poorly.
The manikin attacked like lightning, felling anyone touched by his cudgel, rendering them unable to move.
Terrified, the king threw himself on the soldier's mercy and, to be allowed to live, gave the soldier his kingdom and his daughter in marriage.

events.text_segment: And now loaded with chains, he was standing at the window of his dungeon, when he chanced to see one of his comrades passing by. The soldier tapped at the pane of glass, and when this man came up, said to him: ‘Be so kind as to fetch me the small bundle I have left lying in the inn, and I will give you a ducat for doing it.’ His comrade ran thither and brought him what he wanted. As soon as the soldier was alone again, he lighted his pipe and summoned the black manikin. ‘Have no fear,’ said the latter to his master. ‘Go wheresoever they take you, and let them do what they will, only take the blue light with you.’ Next day the soldier was tried, and though he had done nothing wicked, the judge condemned him to death. When he was led forth to die, he begged a last favour of the king. ‘What is it?’ asked the king. ‘That I may smoke one more pipe on my way.’ ‘You may smoke three,’ answered the king, ‘but do not imagine that I will spare your life.’ Then the soldier pulled out his pipe and lighted it at the blue light, and as soon as a few wreaths of smoke had ascended, the manikin was there with a small cudgel in his hand, and said: ‘What does my lord command?’ ‘Strike down to earth that false judge there, and his constable, and spare not the king who has treated me so ill.’ Then the manikin fell on them like lightning, darting this way and that way, and whosoever was so much as touched by his cudgel fell to earth, and did not venture to stir again. The king was terrified; he threw himself on the soldier’s mercy, and merely to be allowed to live at all, gave him his kingdom for his own, and his daughter to wife.

events.title: The Queen's Impatient Wish and the Daughter's Transformation
detailed_summary: A queen possessed a young daughter who was behaving quite fretfully one day.
The mother, struggling to calm her child and growing exasperated, observed ravens circling the castle.
In a moment of frustration, she uttered a wish for her daughter to become a raven and fly away, simply so she could have some tranquility.
Her words had an immediate and magical effect: the child she held transformed into a raven.
The newly transformed raven-daughter then flew out through the open window, vanishing into a dense, dark forest.
For a significant period afterward, the parents received no news or sighting of their lost child.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was once a queen who had a little daughter, still too young to run alone.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The bird took its flight to a dark wood and remained there for a long time, and meanwhile the parents could hear nothing of their child.

events.text_segment: There was once a queen who had a little daughter, still too young to run alone. One day the child was very troublesome, and the mother could not quiet it, do what she would. She grew impatient, and seeing the ravens flying round the castle, she opened the window, and said: ‘I wish you were a raven and would fly away, then I should have a little peace.’ Scarcely were the words out of her mouth, when the child in her arms was turned into a raven, and flew away from her through the open window. The bird took its flight to a dark wood and remained there for a long time, and meanwhile the parents could hear nothing of their child.

events.title: The Enchanted Princess's Plea and Instructions for Rescue
detailed_summary: A long time later, a man traversing the forest heard a raven's call and decided to follow the sound.
Upon reaching the raven, she disclosed her true identity as a king's daughter, currently under an enchantment, and explained that he possessed the ability to free her.
When the man inquired about the method, she directed him to proceed further into the woods until he located a house inhabited by an elderly woman.

She cautioned that the old woman would present him with food and drink, but he must abstain from consuming either, as doing so would cause him to fall into a profound sleep, rendering him incapable of assisting her.
His task was to find a large tan-heap situated in the garden behind the house, stand upon it, and await her arrival.

The princess specified she would arrive in her carriage at two o'clock in the afternoon on three consecutive days: the first day with four white horses, the second with four chestnut horses, and the third with four black horses.
She sternly warned that if he failed to remain awake and she found him asleep, her freedom would not be secured.
The man pledged to carry out all her instructions.
Despite his promise, the raven voiced her premonition that he would inevitably accept something from the old woman and thus be unable to save her.
The man reiterated his assurance that he would absolutely not touch any food or drink.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Long after this, a man was making his way through the wood when he heard a raven calling, and he followed the sound of the voice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The man assured her again that he would on no account touch a thing to eat or drink.

events.text_segment:
Long after this, a man was making his way through the wood when he heard a raven calling, and he followed the sound of the voice. As he drew near, the raven said, ‘I am by birth a king’s daughter, but am now under the spell of some enchantment; you can, however, set me free.’ ‘What am I to do?’ he asked. She replied, ‘Go farther into the wood until you come to a house, wherein lives an old woman; she will offer you food and drink, but you must not take of either; if you do, you will fall into a deep sleep, and will not be able to help me. In the garden behind the house is a large tan-heap, and on that you must stand and watch for me. I shall drive there in my carriage at two o’clock in the afternoon for three successive days; the first day it will be drawn by four white, the second by four chestnut, and the last by four black horses; but if you fail to keep awake and I find you sleeping, I shall not be set free.’
The man promised to do all that she wished, but the raven said, ‘Alas! I know even now that you will take something from the woman and be unable to save me.’ The man assured her again that he would on no account touch a thing to eat or drink.

events.title: The First Temptation and Failure at the Tan-Heap
detailed_summary: Upon arriving at the designated house and entering, the man was met by the old woman, who commented on his apparent exhaustion and invited him to rest and accept some food and drink.
The man initially declined her offer, stating his intention to neither eat nor drink.
The old woman, however, was persistent, suggesting that even if he chose not to eat, a mere sip of wine would be inconsequential.
Eventually, the man allowed himself to be convinced and consumed the wine.
As the prearranged time of two o'clock neared, he proceeded to the garden and positioned himself atop the tan-heap to await the raven princess.

An unexpected and overwhelming sensation of fatigue washed over him, and despite his firm resolution to stay awake, he succumbed, lay down, and fell into a sleep so deep that no noise could rouse him.
At two o'clock, the raven princess arrived, her carriage drawn by four white horses.
Even before reaching the tan-heap, she sighed, expressing her sorrowful certainty that he had fallen asleep.
Upon entering the garden, she discovered him, as she had feared, lying on the tan-heap in a deep slumber.
She disembarked from her carriage, approached him, called his name, and shook him, but all her efforts were futile; he remained asleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When he came to the house and went inside, the old woman met him, and said, ‘Poor man! how tired you are! Come in and rest and let me give you something to eat and drink.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She got out of her carriage and went to him; she called him and shook him, but it was all in vain, he still continued sleeping.

events.text_segment:
When he came to the house and went inside, the old woman met him, and said, ‘Poor man! how tired you are! Come in and rest and let me give you something to eat and drink.’
‘No,’ answered the man, ‘I will neither eat not drink.’
But she would not leave him alone, and urged him saying, ‘If you will not eat anything, at least you might take a draught of wine; one drink counts for nothing,’ and at last he allowed himself to be persuaded, and drank.
As it drew towards the appointed hour, he went outside into the garden and mounted the tan-heap to await the raven. Suddenly a feeling of fatigue came over him, and unable to resist it, he lay down for a little while, fully determined, however, to keep awake; but in another minute his eyes closed of their own accord, and he fell into such a deep sleep, that all the noises in the world would not have awakened him. At two o’clock the raven came driving along, drawn by her four white horses; but even before she reached the spot, she said to herself, sighing, ‘I know he has fallen asleep.’ When she entered the garden, there she found him as she had feared, lying on the tan-heap, fast asleep. She got out of her carriage and went to him; she called him and shook him, but it was all in vain, he still continued sleeping.

events.title: The Second Day's Temptation and Continued Failure
detailed_summary: The following day around noon, the old woman once again approached the man, offering him food and drink, which he initially declined.
However, faced with her unyielding insistence that he partake in something, he eventually relented, took the glass, and drank from it again.
As two o'clock approached, he made his way into the garden and onto the tan-heap to keep watch for the raven princess.
He had not been there long before an intense weariness afflicted him, making it difficult for his limbs to support him, and he found himself unable to remain standing.
Consequently, he lay down once more and quickly fell into a profound sleep.
When the raven princess drove up with her four chestnut horses, she remarked sadly to herself, already knowing he would be asleep.
She went to find him, as she had done the previous day, but he was sleeping soundly, and it proved impossible to awaken him.

events.title: The Final Failure, the Raven's Gifts, and New Instructions
detailed_summary: On the third day, the old woman questioned the man's complete abstinence from food and drink, asking if he intended to cause his own demise.
He responded that he was forbidden and unwilling to either eat or drink.
Despite his refusal, she placed a dish of food and a glass of wine before him. The aroma of the wine proved too enticing, and he yielded to the temptation, taking a substantial drink.
When the appointed hour arrived again, he went to the tan-heap in the garden to await the king's daughter, but he felt an even greater weariness than on the preceding two days.
He collapsed onto the heap and slept as soundly as a log.
At two o'clock, the raven princess approached; this time, her coachman, her attire, and her horses were all black.
She appeared more sorrowful than ever as she drove, mournfully acknowledging that he was asleep and would be unable to free her.
She found him deeply asleep, and all her attempts to rouse him were unsuccessful.
Before departing, she placed beside him a loaf of bread, a portion of meat, and a flask of wine, all possessing the magical quality of never diminishing, no matter how much was consumed.
She then removed a gold ring, engraved with her name, from her finger and placed it onto one of his.
Finally, she left a letter near him, detailing the inexhaustible nature of the provisions and concluding with the message that he would never be able to free her as long as he remained there.
The letter further instructed that if he still wished to rescue her, he should journey to the golden castle of Stromberg, an endeavor she stated was well within his capability to achieve.
With these actions completed, she returned to her carriage and drove towards the golden castle of Stromberg.

events.text_segment:
The following day the old woman said to him, ‘What is this? You are not eating or drinking anything, do you want to kill yourself?’
He answered, ‘I may not and will not either eat or drink.’
But she put down the dish of food and the glass of wine in front of him, and when he smelt the wine, he was unable to resist the temptation, and took a deep draught.
When the hour came round again he went as usual on to the tan-heap in the garden to await the king’s daughter, but he felt even more overcome with weariness than on the two previous days, and throwing himself down, he slept like a log. At two o’clock the raven could be seen approaching, and this time her coachman and everything about her, as well as her horses, were black.
She was sadder than ever as she drove along, and said mournfully, ‘I know he has fallen asleep, and will not be able to set me free.’ She found him sleeping heavily, and all her efforts to awaken him were of no avail. Then she placed beside him a loaf, and some meat, and a flask of wine, of such a kind, that however much he took of them, they would never grow less. After that she drew a gold ring, on which her name was engraved, off her finger, and put it upon one of his. Finally, she laid a letter near him, in which, after giving him particulars of the food and drink she had left for him, she finished with the following words: ‘I see that as long as you remain here you will never be able to set me free; if, however, you still wish to do so, come to the golden castle of Stromberg; this is well within your power to accomplish.’ She then returned to her carriage and drove to the golden castle of Stromberg.

When the hour came again, he went into the garden to the tan-heap, but he felt still more weary than on the day before, and lay down on the heap and slept as soundly as a stone. At two o’clock the king’s daughter came, and her coachman, her clothes, and her horses were all black. She was sadder than ever, and drove along mournfully, saying, ‘He is asleep, and cannot set me free.’ She found him fast asleep, and could not wake him. She put a loaf of bread beside him, and a piece of meat, and a flask of wine, which would never come to an end, and took a gold ring from her finger, on which her name was engraved, and put it on one of his. And lastly she laid a letter near him, in which she wrote what the things were, and added that he would never be able to set her free as long as he stayed there, but if he still wished to set her free, he must come to the golden castle of Stromberg, for it was quite within his power to do that. Then she got into her carriage again and drove to the golden castle of Stromberg.

events.title: The Man's Renewed Quest and Encounter with a Hungry Giant
detailed_summary: Upon awakening and realizing he had slept through the princess's visit yet again, the man was deeply distressed, lamenting that she had likely departed and that his chance to save her was lost.
His attention was then drawn to the items lying beside him; he read the letter and fully understood the events that had transpired.
He rose immediately, eager to begin his journey to the castle of Stromberg, though he was entirely unsure of which direction to take.
He wandered for a considerable time in search of it and eventually found himself in a dark forest, through which he walked for fourteen days without discovering an exit.
As night fell once more, exhausted, he lay down beneath a bush and fell asleep.
The next day he continued his journey through the forest, and that evening, intending to rest, he lay down again but was kept awake by terrifying howling and wailing sounds.
He waited until the surroundings grew darker and people began to illuminate their homes, then noticed a faint glimmer of light in the distance and moved towards it.
He discovered the light emanated from a house that seemed smaller than its actual size due to the presence of an enormous giant standing before it.
The man initially feared for his life, thinking the giant would surely harm him if seen, but eventually mustered his courage and approached.
When the giant spotted him, he declared the man's arrival opportune, as he hadn't eaten for a long time and planned to make the man his supper.
The man protested, stating he did not wish to be eaten and offered to satisfy the giant's hunger with the ample provisions he carried.
The giant, upon hearing this offer, agreed to spare him, explaining his intention to eat the man stemmed only from a lack of alternative food.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘I only thought of eating you because I had nothing else.’

events.text_segment:
When the man awoke and found that he had been sleeping, he was grieved at heart, and said, ‘She has no doubt been here and driven away again, and it is now too late for me to save her.’ Then his eyes fell on the things which were lying beside him; he read the letter, and knew from it all that had happened. He rose up without delay, eager to start on his way and to reach the castle of Stromberg, but he had no idea in which direction he ought to go. He travelled about a long time in search of it and came at last to a dark forest, through which he went on walking for fourteen days and still could not find a way out. Once more the night came on, and worn out he lay down under a bush and fell asleep. Again the next day he pursued his way through the forest, and that evening, thinking to rest again, he lay down as before, but he heard such a howling and wailing that he found it impossible to sleep. He waited till it was darker and people had begun to light up their houses, and then seeing a little glimmer ahead of him, he went towards it.
He found that the light came from a house which looked smaller than it really was, from the contrast of its height with that of an immense giant who stood in front of it. He thought to himself, ‘If the giant sees me going in, my life will not be worth much.’ However, after a while he summoned up courage and went forward. When the giant saw him, he called out, ‘It is lucky for that you have come, for I have not had anything to eat for a long time. I can have you now for my supper.’ ‘I would rather you let that alone,’ said the man, ‘for I do not willingly give myself up to be eaten; if you are wanting food I have enough to satisfy your hunger.’ ‘If that is so,’ replied the giant, ‘I will leave you in peace; I only thought of eating you because I had nothing else.’
